Nigeria, Weekly Epidemiology Report (WER-Nigeria, 2012 (Vol. 2: No.26) [edited]\n<nigeriaepidnews@yahoo.com>\n\nLassa fever update as at 6th July, 2012\n--------------------------------\n2.1 - As at 6th July 2012, a total of 933 suspected Lassa fever cases, 147 laboratory confirmed and 93 deaths (CFR 9.97%) were reported from 41 LGAs [local government agencies] in 23 States.\n2.2. - In the reporting week 26 (2012), no suspected case was reported in any part of Nigeria while intensive surveillance and case search are ongoing.\n2.3. - Adequate quantities of Ribavirin drugs and PPEs [personal protective equipment?] were prepositioned in all affected States.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the previous ProMED-mail from Nigeria, dated 9 Jul 2012, this the number of cases has risen by 78 and the number of fatalities by 6 (see: Lassa fever - Nigeria (07): neglected disease 20120709.1195196).\n\nThis statement has a less alarmist tone than than the previous report from Nigeria and indicates that no new cases are being detected as a consequence of enhanced surveillance. Furthermore it states that supplies of ribavirin, the only drug known to be effective in treatment of Lassa fever virus infection, are adequate and generally available.\n\nRibavirin (brand names: Copegus, Rebetol, Ribasphere, Vilona and Virazole) is an anti-viral drug indicated for severe respiratory syncytial virus infection (individually), hepatitis C infection (used in conjunction with peginterferon alfa-2b or peginterferon alfa-2a) and other viral infections. Ribavirin is a prodrug, which when metabolised resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this form it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral replication. How it exactly affects viral replication is unknown; many mechanisms have been proposed for this but none of these has been proven to date. Multiple mechanisms may be responsible for its actions. The primary observed serious adverse side-effect of ribavirin is hemolytic anemia, which may worsen preexisting cardiac disease. The mechanism for this effect is unknown. It is dose-dependent and may sometimes be compensated by decreasing dose.\n\nRibavirin is active against a number of DNA and RNA viruses. It is a member of the nucleoside antimetabolite drugs that interfere with duplication of viral genetic material. Though not effective against all viruses, ribavirin is remarkable as a small molecule for its wide range of activity, including important activities against influenzas, flaviviruses and agents of many viral hemorrhagic fevers including Lassa fever. (See: http://www.news-medical.net/health/Ribavirin-What-is-Ribavirin.aspx.)\n\nThe HealthMap interactive map of Nigeria is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1qG. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Federal Ministry of Health - Nigeria, Weekly Epidemiology Report (WER-Nigeria, 2012 (Vol. 2: No.26) [edited]\n<nigeriaepidnews@yahoo.com>\n\nLassa fever update as at 6th July, 2012\n --------------------------------\n2.1 - As at 6th July 2012, a total of 933 suspected Lassa fever cases, 147 laboratory confirmed and 93 deaths (CFR 9.97%) were reported from 41 LGAs [local government agencies] in 23 States. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the previous ProMED-mail from Nigeria, dated 9 Jul 2012, this the number of cases has risen by 78 and the number of fatalities by 6 (see: Lassa fever - Nigeria (07): neglected disease 20120709.1195196). Ribavirin (brand names: Copegus, Rebetol, Ribasphere, Vilona and Virazole) is an anti-viral drug indicated for severe respiratory syncytial virus infection (individually), hepatitis C infection (used in conjunction with peginterferon alfa-2b or peginterferon alfa-2a) and other viral infections. LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (08): UPDATE\n**********************************\n Though not effective against all viruses, ribavirin is remarkable as a small molecule for its wide range of activity, including important activities against influenzas, flaviviruses and agents of many viral hemorrhagic fevers including Lassa fever. The Commissioner for Health, Dr Jide Idris, who disclosed this in Lagos, explained that the message to the residents became necessary to stem a possible outbreak of the disease in the state in the wake of reported cases in [other] parts of the country.\n\nDr Idris, who urged members of the public to avoid contact with rats, [instructed] them to cover their food and water properly, while ensuring that they cook all their food thoroughly, as well as block all rat hideouts and holes through which rats could enter the house. The commissioner also counseled the residents to store their grains and other dried food items in containers with covers, as well as keeping pets like cats in the house.\n\nHe explained that Lassa fever is an acute viral infection caused by Lassa virus associated with persistent high fever, and added that as the disease progresses into a severe form, the patient begins to develop facial swelling, fluid in the chest, bleeding from the mouth, nose, vagina, and gut, low blood pressure, shock, disorientation, coma, and kidney and liver failure. According to him, other usual symptoms include general weakness, malaise, headache, sore throat, nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. 'Lassa fever is an acute viral infection caused by the Lassa virus and associated with persistent high fever. It is spread by exposure to and eating of foods contaminated with rat droppings or urine. It is also spread by direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of person with Lassa fever,' Idris noted. He urged members of the public to report the case of anybody with the symptoms above, or persistent high fever that is not responding to standard treatment for malaria and typhoid fever, to the nearest health facility in the state.\n\nThe Commissioner noted that though Lagos state is not in the Lassa fever belt region, members of the public should practice adequate personal and environmental hygiene at all times to avert an outbreak of the disease in the state.\n\n[Byline: George Okojie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the 'multimammate rat.' _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta. A photograph of a multimammate rat can be viewed at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mastomys.jpg.\n\nLassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea (Conakry), Liberia, Sierra Leone, and parts of Nigeria, but probably exists in other West African countries as well. About 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. The incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. Lassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women. Persons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where _Mastomys_ rats are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper barrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from direct contact with rat droppings or urine and through touching objects or eating food contaminated with rat droppings or urine of infected _Mastomys_. Lassa virus may also be spread between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health care settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical equipment, such as re-used needles.\n\nPrevention of Lassa fever in the community centers on promoting good 'community hygiene' to discourage rodents from entering homes. Effective measures include storing grain and other foodstuffs in rodent-proof containers, disposing of garbage far from the home, maintaining clean households and keeping cats. Because _Mastomys_ are so abundant in endemic areas, it is not possible to completely eliminate them from the environment. Further information can be accessed at http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html.\n\nLagos State is an administrative division of Nigeria, located in the southwestern part of the country. The smallest in area of Nigeria's states, Lagos State is the most economically important state of the country, containing Lagos, the nation's largest urban area. According to him: 'the virus which primary carrier are the rodents genus has between 1969 when it was first confirmed to be in Lassa (a north eastern community in today's Borno state) and May this year, had claimed 86 000 lives in Nigeria alone.\n\nEvery year, Lassa fever is reported to affect about 300 000 to 500 000 people resulting in over 5000 deaths across the west African countries of Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.\n\nProf. Agbonlahor expressed concern that measures being taken by the state and federal governments were grossly inadequate, noting that attentions had been more focused on the western world, propelled by emphasis on diseases such as HIV/AIDS, malaria and others, whereas Lassa [haemorrhagic] fever, which has so far proven to be an African mass killer disease, has been neglected.\n\n[Byline: Julius Osahon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa haemorrhagic fever is a viral illness that is spread by rodents, predominantly the 'multimammate mouse/rat' _Mastomys natalensis_. People get the disease through direct contact with rat droppings or urine and through touching objects or eating food contaminated with rat droppings or urine. Lassa fever may also spread though person-to-person contact. The symptoms include fever, pain behind the chest, sore throat, back pain, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding from the mouth or nose. People with Lassa fever may also experience hearing loss, tremors, swelling of the face and eyelids, and swelling of the brain. Pregnant women with Lassa fever often have bleeding from the genitals and miscarriage and may die from the illness.\n\nLassa fever is seen in West Africa. Cases have been documented in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Nigeria. However, the rats that spread Lassa fever also live in other countries in Africa, and there is the potential for further spread of the disease. The number of Lassa virus infections per year in West Africa is estimated at 100 000 to 300 000, with about 5000 deaths. These numbers are estimates because cases are not investigated everywhere. In some areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia, 10 per cent to 16 per cent of people admitted to hospitals have Lassa fever, which indicates the serious impact of the disease on the population of this region. Lassa fever can occur all year long, but most cases occur from January to May.\n\nBecause airborne transmission is possible and mortality can be high under certain conditions, Lassa virus has been classified as a category A bioterrorism agent. Early diagnosis is difficult due to insidious non-specific onset and to the great genetic divergence of the virus that makes RT-PCR assays unreliable. The lack of proper diagnostic tools promotes nosocomial infection and diminishes the efficacy of treatment. (See: Leparc-Goffart I, Emonet SF. As of 22 Mar 2012, 623 suspected cases, including 70 deaths have been recorded from 19 of the 36 States since the beginning of the year. Laboratory analysis undertaken at the Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital, Irrua Edo State has confirmed the presence of Lassa virus infection in 108 patients. 3 doctors and 4 nurses were reported to be among the fatalities. This information is provisional and subject to change when laboratory results for Lassa fever in suspected cases become available.\n\nThe Federal and State governments are responding to the outbreak by enhancing the disease surveillance for early detection, reinforcing treatment of patients, and conducting awareness campaigns among the affected population. Major challenges are the ongoing security risks in the country limiting access to some areas as well as the limited availability of resources to respond to the escalating outbreak.\n\nWHO does not advise or recommend any restrictions on travel or trade with Nigeria. Travellers returning from affected areas who develop symptoms of fever, malaise, headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal pain should seek medical advice.\n\nPeople usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to infected rodents belonging to _Mastomys_ [genus]. Person-to-person transmission occurs through direct contact with sick patients in both community and health care settings. Those at greatest risk are persons living in rural areas where _Mastomys_ [rodents] are found. Health care workers are at risk if adequate infection control practices are not maintained.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[A previous ProMED-mail report dated 22 Feb 2012 stated that in the 1st 6 weeks of 2012 there had been 392 cases of Lassa fever and 40 fatalites across the country. The Minister of Health reported at that time that 6 of the dead were health workers (2 doctors and 4 nurses) and that cases have been reported in 12 states: Edo, Nasarawa, Plateau, Ebonyi, Taraba, Yobe, Ondo, Rivers, Gombe, Anambra, Delta, and Lagos. Currently the outbreak has spread to at least 19 of the 36 states of Nigeria and the total number cases now exceeds 623 with 70 fatalities.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic with the remainder experiencing severe multi-system disease with the virus affecting several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease and the animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the 'multimammate rat.' _Mastomys_ rodents infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta. In the absence of an effective vaccine, rodent control would seem the best option for control of the current outbreak.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to excreta of infected _Mastomys_ rodents, and the infection may spread further between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health care settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical equipment, such as re-used needles. Sexual transmission of Lassa virus has been reported.\n\nLassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases that cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever, and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. He said the ministry had already taken measures to stop the spread of the epidemic and would embark on sensitisation campaigns as well as vaccinate the entire people of the state against the disease. \n\nA map of Nigeria showing the locations of the 3 states (Ebonyi, Rivers and Taraba) reporting outbreaks of Lassa fever so far in 2012 can be accessed at: http://www.waado.org/nigerdelta/Maps/Nigeria_States.html.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "lassa fever", "malaria", "shigellosis", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-09 00:00:00", "2012-02-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taraba State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jalingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gombe State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taraba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ebonyi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1117076", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - Nigeria (06) travel alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1117076", "date": "2012-04-28 13:12:53", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA (06) TRAVEL ALERT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 25 Apr 2012\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Travellers' Health [abridged & edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/in-the-news/lassa-fever-in-nigeria.htm\n\n\nLassa Fever in Nigeria\n----------------------\nThe Nigerian Federal Ministry of Health has reported an increased number of cases of Lassa [haemorrhagic fever]. Nineteen of the country's 36 states have reported cases since the beginning of 2012. As of April 13, 2012, there were reports of 818 suspected cases, including 84 deaths. At this time, 131 cases have been confirmed by laboratory testing. Seven deaths have also been reported among health care workers. Cases have occurred in the states of Edo, Bauchi, Plateau, and Taraba. The number of reported cases of Lassa fever in Nigeria is greater this year than in previous years. However, cases in previous years could have been underestimated due to the lack of laboratory and disease investigation systems. The Nigerian government is responding to the outbreak by improving the disease investigation, treatment of patients, and conducting awareness campaigns among affected populations. Security and availability of resources are proving to be a major challenge. WHO does not advise or recommend any restrictions on travel or trade with Nigeria.\n\nLassa fever is a viral illness that is spread by rats [classically the 'multimammate mouse' _Mastomys natalensis_, also dubbed 'rat']. People get the disease through direct contact with rat droppings or urine and through touching objects or eating food contaminated with rat droppings or urine. Lassa fever may also spread though person-to-person contact. This happens when a person comes into contact with an infected person\u2019s blood, tissue, or body fluids. The symptoms include fever, pain behind the chest, sore throat, back pain, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding from the mouth or nose. People with Lassa fever may also experience hearing loss, tremors, swelling of the face and eyelids, and swelling of the brain. Pregnant women with Lassa fever often have bleeding from the genitals and miscarriage and may die from the illness.\n\nLassa fever is seen in West Africa. Cases have been documented in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Nigeria. However, the rats that spread Lassa fever also live in other countries in Africa. The number of Lassa virus infections per year in West Africa is estimated at 100 000 to 300 000, with about 5000 deaths. These numbers are estimates because cases are not investigated everywhere. In some areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia, 10 per cent to 16 per cent of people admitted to hospitals have Lassa fever, which indicates the serious impact of the disease on the population of this region. Lassa fever can occur all year long, but most cases occur from January to May.\n\nHow can travelers protect themselves? Avoid contact with rats, especially rat urine and feces. Put food away in rodent-proof containers. Keep the home clean and rodent proof. Trap rats in and around homes. Do not eat rats. Wash hands well and often with soap, and teach children to wash their hands, too. Do not share eating or drinking utensils. Clean surfaces that are frequently touched (such as toys, doorknobs, tables, and counters) regularly with soap and water or with cleaning wipes. Avoid close contact with sick people.\n\nIf you have traveled to the area and develop symptoms of fever, headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, see a doctor or health care provider right away. Be sure to tell your doctor or health care provider that you have recently traveled to Nigeria.\n\nFor additional information, see:\n\nLassa fever (CDC, Special Pathogens Branch) http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/lassaf.htm.\n\nViral hemorrhagic fevers (CDC Yellow Book, Health Information for International Travel) http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2012/chapter-3-infectious-diseases-related-to-travel/viral-hemorrhagic-fevers.htm.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Curiously this travel alert identifies only 4 of the 19 states affected by the outbreak of Lassa fever -- Edo, Bauchi, Plateau, and Taraba, whereas the Nigerian Ministry of Health had reported previously that Lassa fever was affecting 12 states -- Edo, Nasarawa, Plu, Ebonyi, Taraba, Yobe, Ondo, Rivers, Gombe, Anambra, Delta, and Lagos [see ProMED-mail report 'Lassa fever - Nigeria (04) 20120223.1050129'].\n\nAbout 80 per cent of human infections are asymptomatic with the remainder experiencing severe multi-system disease with the virus affecting several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease and the animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the 'multimammate rat'. _Mastomys_ rodents infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta. In the absence of an effective vaccine, rodent control would seem the best option for control of the current outbreak. Images of multimammate rats be viewed at http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=mastomys&hl=en&prmd=imvns&tbm=isch&tbo=u&source=univ&sa=X&ei=TRScT7zkLdCo8QPc0sGyBA&sqi=2&ved=0CEsQsAQ&biw=1008&bih=404.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to excreta of infected _Mastomys_ rodents, and the infection may spread further between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is little epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health care settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical equipment, such as reused needles. Sexual transmission of Lassa virus has been reported. (For further information see: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html).\n\nA map showing the locations of the provinces of Nigeria can be accessed at http://www.ngex.com/nigeria/places/. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1qGF.]", "summary": "\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to excreta of infected _Mastomys_ rodents, and the infection may spread further between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. \n\nIf you have traveled to the area and develop symptoms of fever, headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, see a doctor or health care provider right away. People should wash their fruits and vegetables with water before consumption.'\n\nThe commissioner said officers from the Ministry of Health had been sent to various communities to inform the people about the disease and educate them on what to do once the symptoms are detected in their areas. 'We are not taking chances, and we want to be pro-active in our approach to this development.'\n\nHe said the government had in stock available drugs to treat the fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease and humans become infected as a result of contact with infected animals. So far, 397 cases have been reported and all patients are to be treated free. This was disclosed in a statement by the minister of health, Prof Onyebuchi Chukwu, yesterday [21 Feb 2012]. The minister said that 6 of the dead were health workers (2 doctors and 4 nurses) and that cases have been reported in 12 states Edo, Nasarawa, Plateau, Ebonyi, Taraba, Yobe, Ondo, Rivers, Gombe, Anambra, Delta, and Lagos.\n\nOut of the 397 cases reported, only 87 cases have been positively confirmed by medical officials. Chukwu narrated the case of a 28-year-old female corps member who completed her 3 weeks orientation in Rivers State but travelled home to visit her families in Afikpo and Abakiliki, capital of Ebonyi State, where she contracted the fever on 1 Jan 2012 and died 2 days later.\n\nOn what the Ministry is doing to contain the situation, Chukwu said adequate quantities of ribavirin injections and tablets, the specific antiviral drug for Lassa fever, have been released to the affected states. He also said that the ministry has deployed rapid response teams to all affected states and there is great emphasis on routine barrier nursing precautions. Chukwu added that no travel restriction will be imposed on the affected areas but hotlines have been provided for health workers for expert advice. The numbers are: 08037154575, 08023214998, 08037879701, and 08023047101.\n\nHowever, the minister of state for health, Dr Muhammad Ali Pate, in a media conference yesterday [21 Feb 2012], said the ministry has also distributed over 750 000 ribavirin doses of injection and tablets as well as safety gloves and protective vests for health workers. He said that there are 9 specialist centres across Nigeria where tests on Lassa fever can be done. Pate advised Nigerians not to panic as the government is responding promptly and effectively to the outbreak.\n\nLassa fever is a viral disease that attacks the liver, nervous system, spleen, and kidney, causing them to bleed, hence the haemorrhagic fever designation. According to the online encyclopaedia Wikipedia, Lassa fever was first described in 1969 in the town of Lassa, in Borno State, Nigeria, in the Yedseram river valley at the south end of Lake Chad. It is an infection that is endemic in the West African countries of Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea, and even Central African Republic and Congo DR. About 300 000 to 500 000 cases occur annually, with approximately 5000 deaths. Symptoms of Lassa fever include fever, retrosternal pain (pain behind the chest wall), sore throat, back pain, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, conjunctivitis, facial swelling, proteinuria (protein in the urine), and mucosal bleeding, bleeding from the mouth, nose, vagina, or gastrointestinal tract and low blood pressure.\n\nThe virus lives in rats and infects humans when they come in contact with these rats' urine and faeces. Pate explained that increasing awareness is being created for Nigerians to avoid rats and keep them away from stored food and drinking water. People living in rural areas or in crowded and unsanitary environments, where rats breed, are at the greatest risk. However, health experts warn that Lassa fever can be contracted through body fluids like blood and excrements of infected persons.\n\n[Byline: Ezra Ijioma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRichard A 'Ran' Nisbett, PhD, MSPH\nAssistant Professor\nGlobal Health Practices Track\nDepartment of Global Health\nCollege of Public Health\nUniversity of South Florida\n13201 Bruce B Downs Blvd, MDC56\nTampa, FL 33612-3805\nUSA\nResearch Associate\nPIRE-University of Liberia\n<rnisbett@health.usf.edu>\n\n[About 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Lassa virus may also be spread between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health care settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical equipment, such as re-used needles. Sexual transmission of Lassa virus has been reported.\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women. Persons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where _Mastomys_ rats are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper barrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained. Because the symptoms of Lassa fever are so varied and non-specific, clinical diagnosis is often difficult, especially early in the course of the disease. Lassa fever is difficult to distinguish from many other diseases that cause fever, including malaria, shigellosis, typhoid fever, yellow fever, and other viral haemorrhagic fevers. Some other doctors are being treated for the disease at the Federal Teaching Hospital (FTH), Abakaliki [capital of Ebonyi State].\n\nThough no official confirmation has been made by the Ministry of Health, doctors have raised the alarm over the outbreak of the disease. Some doctors at the FTH, who spoke to our reporter, regretted the outbreak of the disease, adding that doctors are prone to it since they are exposed to infected patients. The doctors called for quick intervention by the Federal Ministry of Health to forestall the spread of the disease.\n\nAn outbreak of Lassa fever was first reported in the state in 2008. Several people died. They included 2 doctors and other health workers. Last year [2011], 4 people said to be residing at the Military cantonment, Nkwoagu, near Abakaliki also died of the disease.\n\nThe government said it has set up an emergency response team for the treatment and control of outbreaks of communicable diseases, such as Lassa fever, gastroenteritis, and meningitis, usually associated with dry season. The commissioner for health, Sunday Nwangele, said this while addressing stakeholders in Abakaliki. Nwangele said epidemiologists from the ministry had been deployed to health facilities in the state to check the possible spread of the disease. He urged the people to report any suspected case to a hospital or the epidemiology unit of the ministry. According to him the disease had, in 2008, claimed the lives of some people including 2 medical doctors and other health workers and last year [2011], 4 people said to be residing at the Military cantonment, Nkwoagu near Abakaliki also died of the disease.\n\nHe said the recent case of the outbreak of the disease was being controlled by epidemiologists from the state ministry of health, who had been deployed to health facilities in parts of the state to check the possible spread of the disease. Though the commissioner said that the chief medical director was brought to the teaching hospital in a critical condition before he gave up, he urged the people not to panic but report any suspected case to a hospital or Epidemiology unit of the ministry for prompt medical attention.\n\nThe head of the epidemiology unit of the ministry, Dr Francis Onwe, said the unit had commenced the distribution of the drugs to hospitals across the state and advised people to report to hospitals if they experience symptoms such as stooling and vomiting of blood among others.\n\n[byline: Nnamdi Akpa]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo, DVM\nCoordinator\nZoonotic Diseases Unit\nMinistry of Health\nRiyadh\nSaudi Arabia\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4 weeks duration that occurs in West Africa. The virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family Arenaviridae. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea (Conakry), Liberia, Sierra Leone, and parts of Nigeria, but probably exists in other West African countries as well.\n\nAbout 80 per cent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen, and kidneys. The incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. The onset of the disease is usually gradual, starting with fever, general weakness, and malaise. After a few days, headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, cough, and abdominal may follow. Severe cases may progress to show facial swelling, fluid in the lung cavity, bleeding from mouth, nose, vagina, or gastrointestinal tract, and low blood pressure. Protein may be noted in the urine. Shock, seizures, tremor, disorientation, and coma may be seen in the late stages. Deafness occurs in 25 per cent of patients of whom half recover some function after 1-3 months.\n\nLassa fever is a zoonotic disease, humans becoming infected from contact with infected animals. The animal reservoir of Lassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the 'multimammate rat'. Mastomys infected with Lassa virus do not become ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta (urine and faeces).\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to excreta of infected _Mastomys_ rats. Lassa virus may also be spread between humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health care settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical equipment.\n\nFurther information can be obtained from the WHO website at http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/1F4_. Robertson, PhD\nSenior Technical Advisor\nVaccine Development Global Program\nPATH\n455 Massachusetts Ave NW, Suite 1000\nWashington, DC 20001 USA\n<grobertson@path.org>\n\n[Lassa fever is an acute viral zoonotic illness caused by Lassa virus,\nan arenavirus known to be responsible for a severe haemorrhagic fever\ncharacterised by fever, muscle aches, sore throat, nausea, vomiting,\nand chest and abdominal pain. The virus exhibits persistent,\nasymptomatic infection with profuse urinary virus excretion in the\nubiquitous rodent vector, _Mastomys natalensis_. Lassa fever is\nendemic in West Africa and has been reported from Sierra Leone,\nGuinea, Liberia, and Nigeria, but not previously from Ghana. Some\nstudies indicate that 300 000 to 500 000 cases of Lassa fever and 5000\ndeaths occur yearly across West Africa. (From: Lassa fever in West\nAfrican sub-region: an overview. Ogbu O, Ajuluchukwu E, Uneke CJ. J\nVector Borne Dis. 2007 Mar;44(1):1-11).\n\nLassa virus infection has not been not recorded previously in Ghana,\nbut the lesser prevalence of Lassa fever in Ghana was predicted by a\nspatial-climatic analysis of Lassa fever data from human cases and\ninfected rodent hosts in West Africa during the period 1965-2007 (See:\nRisk maps of Lassa fever in West Africa. PLoS Negl Trop Dis.\n2009;3(3):e388)\nhttp://www.plosntds.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pntd.0000388;jsessionid=A18CA8161C084054F4225595CF9E71CB\nand also the ProMED-mail archived report: Lassa fever, predictive maps\n- West Africa 20090428.1605). In this survey, information on\ncontemporary environmental conditions (temperature, rainfall,\nvegetation) was derived from the NASA Terra MODIS satellite sensor\ndata and other sources and for elevation from the GTOPO30 surface for\nthe region from Senegal to the Congo. All multi-temporal data were\nanalysed using temporal Fourier techniques to generate images of\nmeans, amplitudes and phases, which were used as the predictor\nvariables in 3 different models. In addition, meteorological rainfall\ndata collected between 1951 and 1989 were used to generate a synoptic\nrainfall surface for the same region.\n\nLassa fever-favourable areas predicted by 3 different models covered\napproximately 80 percent of each of Sierra Leone and Liberia, 50\npercent of Guinea, 40 percent of Nigeria, 30 percent of each of Cote\nd'Ivoire, Togo and Benin, and 10 percent of Ghana. Sweden: (LG) ex West Africa\n20110309.0766]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following background data on Lassa fever among travelers and\nexpatriates have been abstracted from the Gideon e-book series. [1].\n\nA total of 12 cases of Lassa fever were imported into Europe and\nNorth America during 1970 to 2000, with no secondary cases among\nmedical staff or patients.\n- 4 cases were imported into Europe in 2000;\n- 6 cases were imported into the UK during 1976 to 2003, none\nresulting in secondary cases.\n\nChronology\n----------\n1969 - the 1st reported case of Lassa fever was that of an American\nnurse working in Lassa, Nigeria.\n1971 - a nurse and physician from UK developed nonfatal Lassa fever\nin Sierra Leone.\n1972 - a nurse from UK developed nonfatal Lassa fever in Sierra\nLeone.\n1974 - a German physician contracted Lassa fever (nonfatal) in\nNigeria.\n1975 - an American aid worker developed nonfatal Lassa fever in\nSierra Leone.\n1976 - a Peace Corps worker returned to the United States from Sierra\nLeone with Lassa fever.\n1980 - a case of Lassa fever (nonfatal) acquired in Burkina Faso was\nreported in the Netherlands.\n1984 - a British geologist developed nonfatal Lassa fever in Sierra\nLeone.\n1985 - a British nurse developed nonfatal Lassa fever in Sierra\nLeone.\n1987 - a case of Lassa fever (nonfatal) was reported in Israel -- an\nengineer who had been in Liberia and Sierra Leone.\n1987 - a traveler developed Lassa fever in 1987 after returning to\nJapan.\n1989 - a Canadian agricultural specialist developed Lassa fever\n(nonfatal) in Nigeria.\n1999 - a woman died of Lassa fever after returning to Germany from\nthe Ivory Coast.\n2000 - a Nigerian national died of Lassa fever after transfer to\nGermany for treatment.\n2000 - a case of Lassa fever (fatal) from Sierra Leone was reported\nin the Netherlands.\n2000 - a student died of Lassa fever in Germany after traveling\nthrough Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, and Ghana.\n2000 - a British national acquired Lassa fever in Sierra Leone, and\ndied while under treatment in England.\n2000 to 2001 - 4 Ghanaian soldiers serving in Sierra Leone contracted\nLassa fever.\n2003 - a British national acquired Lassa fever in Sierra Leone, and\nwas treated successfully in the UK.\n2004 - a man died of Lassa fever in the United States following a\ntrip to Liberia and Sierra Leone.\n2005 - 2 Pakistani soldiers died of Lassa fever in Liberia.\n2006 - a man was hospitalized with Lassa fever in Germany, following\ntravel to Sierra Leone.\n2008 - an outbreak (5 cases, 4 fatal) of Lujo virus (a related agent)\ninfection in South Africa followed hospitalization of an index patient\nfrom Zambia.\n2009 - 2 men died of Lassa fever in England -- one following travel\nto Nigeria, and one following travel to Mali.\n2010 - an American traveler acquired Lassa fever in Liberia; and a\nSouth African civil engineer died of Lassa Fever in Sierra Leone.\n2011 - a Swedish woman acquired Lassa fever in West Africa [described\nin the ProMED-mail post referenced above. - Mod.CP].\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Sierra Leone (03): (NO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=553468", "date": "2010-10-17 18:00:04", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - SIERRA LEONE (03): (NORTHERN)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 17 Oct 2010\nFrom: Daniel Bausch <dbausch@tulane.edu>\n\n\nre: Lassa fever -- Sierra Leone (02): (NO) 20101008.3662\n--------------------------------------------------------\nWe are writing to provide further information regarding the recent postings\non Lassa fever in Sierra Leone:\n\n1. The index case was a 17 year old pregnant woman who delivered at 28\nweeks gestational age. Both she and the baby (not a 6 year old) died.\nAlthough she and her family occasionally caught and consumed rodents, there\nis no history of her running a 'rat meat restaurant'.\n\n2. In all, there were 35 identified contacts of this woman and child, but\nonly 4 developed Lassa fever. All had direct contact with the index case or\nsecondary cases, and all 4 survived. We have not identified any more cases,\nand, since the time from the last known contact of any of the confirmed\ncases has now exceeded the 3-week maximum incubation period for Lassa\nfever, we do not anticipate more cases related to this particular chain of\ntransmission.\n\n3. Whether 'the disease has migrated from the forest region of the east to\nthe savannah grasslands of the north' is a very open question. The index\ncase denied travel to the known endemic area in the east, but it is always\npossible that the infection resulted from unrecognized contact from an\ninfected person coming from the east to her village in Bombali District.\nOur zoology team is presently trapping rodents in the home and village of\nthe index case. Identification of Lassa virus-positive _Mastomys\nnatalensis_ would confirm the notion that the endemic area has expanded.\nHowever, it should be noted that suspected cases of Lassa fever have been\nreported from this area before, but laboratory facilities were not\navailable at the time to confirm them.\n\n4. There has indeed been a significant increase in reported cases of Lassa\nfever in Sierra Leone over the last 9 months or so. However, this\nobservation largely coincides with the implementation of Sierra Leone's new\npolicy of providing free care to children under 5 and pregnant and\nlactating mothers (<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8645968.stm>). The numbers\nof patients seen in hospitals and health clinics sky-rocketed, driving\nupward the perceived incidence of virtually every disease that affects\nthese groups, including Lassa fever. Whether the observed increase in cases\nof Lassa fever is purely reflective of the change in policy or also has\nconcomitant biological determinants is unknown. It should also be noted\nthat, for reasons unknown, there is significant seasonal and yearly\nfluctuation in the incidence of Lassa fever.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nFoday Dafae, MD\nNational Disease Surveillance Coordinator, Sierra Leone\nMinistry of Health and Sanitation\nJames Bangura\nLassa Fever Surveillance Coordinator, Eastern Province,\nSierra Leone Ministry of Health and Sanitation\nDaniel Bausch, MD, MPH&TM\nDirector, Tulane University Research and Training Program in the Mano River\nUnion Countries of West Africa\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Daniel Bausch and colleagues for these valuable\nfirst-hand observations on the Lassa fever situation in the Northern region\nof Sierra Leone, and for correcting some aspects of the previous report.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sierra Leone is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0bj5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 17 Oct 2010\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nFoday Dafae, MD\nNational Disease Surveillance Coordinator, Sierra Leone\nMinistry of Health and Sanitation\n We have not identified any more cases,\nand, since the time from the last known contact of any of the confirmed\ncases has now exceeded the 3-week maximum incubation period for Lassa\nfever, we do not anticipate more cases related to this particular chain of\ntransmission. The woman was infected in West\nAfrica, where she had been working for a humanitarian aid\norganization. She is the 1st patient ever to be treated for Lassa\nfever in Sweden.\n\nThe woman's condition is stable, but she will remain isolated for\nanother few weeks, according to infectious disease specialist Britt\nAkerlind. The woman, who is in her 30s, was flown home on a medical\ntransport flight and arrived in Sweden on Monday [7 Mar 2011] morning.\n'She tested positive for the disease in Africa. We have since\nconducted some tests here, but the results are not in yet. We are\ntreating this as a serious illness,' Akerlind told news agency TT.\n\nThe symptoms of Lassa fever, which infects between 300 000 and 500\n000 people annually, include a high temperature and internal\nhaemorrhaging, but the majority of those that contract the disease\nmake a full recovery. 'Only about one per cent of those infected\nbecome seriously ill, and it is impossible to know in advance who will\nbe affected worse than others,' Akerlind told TT.\n\nRodents are often carriers of Lassa fever, and the disease is spread\nthrough contact with their faeces. Between humans, the disease is\npassed through the exchange of bodily fluids. How the Swedish woman\ncaught the disease is unknown.\n\nAccording to Akerlind there is no risk that Lassa fever, which claims\naround 5000 lives annually, will spread in Sweden.\n\n'There is no threat to the public whatsoever,' she told TT.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Importation of Lassa fever from West Africa into Europe and the\nUnited States has occurred occasionally in the past. Although unconfirmed, reports\nclaim that 3 other persons believed to be residing at the military\ncantonment have also died of the disease. The Commissioner for Health\nand Environment in the state, Dr. Sunday Nwangele, who confirmed the\noutbreak of the disease, said, however, that the state Ministry of\nHealth is on top of the situation.\n\nThe disease was 1st reported in the state in 2008, which then claimed\nthe lives of some people, including 2 medical doctors and other health\nworkers.\n\nThe Nigerian Compass newspaper gathered that the victim of the recent\nincident resided at the Military Cantonment, Nkwegu, near Abakaliki.\nAnother woman in the same cantonment, who has also been diagnosed with\nthe disease, is said to be receiving treatment at the Ebonyi State\nUniversity Teaching Hospital.\n\nAccording to the commissioner, epidemiologists from the ministry have\nbeen deployed to the affected area and other parts of the state to\ncheck the possible spread of the disease. Nwangele said the ministry\nhas sent protective kits to the state's teaching hospital for the\nsafety of health personnel.\n\nThe Chief Medical Director of the teaching hospital, Dr. Akuma Aja,\nnarrated how the victims were brought to the health facility. He said\nthe hospital took samples from neighbours and relatives, who had close\ncontacts with them, as well as health personnel who attended to them\nwhile on admission, stressing that some of the results tested positive\nto the disease.\n\nAja advised people in the state to keep their environment clean and\navoid contact with rodents and rats, which have been identified to be\nresponsible for the transmission of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4 weeks duration\nthat occurs in West Africa. Though 1st described in the 1950s, the\nvirus causing the disease was not identified until 1969. The virus is\na single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family\n_Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea, Liberia,\nSierra Leone and parts of Nigeria but probably exists in other West\nAfrican countries as well. About 80 percent of human infections are\nasymptomatic; the remaining cases have severe multi-system disease,\nwhere the virus affects several organs in the body, such as the liver,\nspleen and kidneys. The incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from\n6-21 days.\n\nLassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa\nvirus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the\n'multimammate rat.' _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not become\nill, but they can shed the virus in their urine and faeces. (An image\nof a multimammate rat can be viewed at:\n<http://www15.bni-hamburg.de/bni/bni2/neu2/getfile.acgi?area=forschunggruppen&pid=21232>).\n\nLassa fever can affect all age groups. Persons at greatest risk are\nthose living in rural areas where _Mastomys_ are usually found,\nespecially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions\nsuch as, in the present instance, military encampments. There is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans,\nbut person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings.\n\nLassa virus was named after the town of Lassa in northeastern\nNigeria, where the 1st known patient contracted this infection in\n1969. Lassa viral infection may affect between 2 to 3 million people\neach year in certain portions of the West African region, causing a\nmortality of about 10 000. Lassa fever is one of the endemic zoonoses\nin Nigeria, with a high probability for nosocomial transmission due to\nseveral health care sector challenges. Although treatment is available\nfor Lassa fever, early diagnosis is still difficult in almost all\nNigerian health care institutions. (For a recent review, see, V.\nIdemyor, Lassa virus infection in Nigeria: clinical perspective\noverview. The\nincubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. Deafness\noccurs in 25 percent of patients of whom half recover some function\nafter 1-3 months. Rogers, PhD\n\n\nWe were struck by the remarks of the ProMED moderator following the\nreport of Lassa fever cases originating in Nigeria but treated in\nboth the UK (a returning UK national) and South Africa (a Nigerian\nmedical doctor, presumed to have been treating Lassa fever patients\nfrom around Abuj-a, [see: Lassa fever - South Africa ex Nigeria\n20090425.1554. Please note that this report actually referred to an\nincident that occurred in 2007 and has since been corrected in report\n20090428.1603], although one wonders in this case why the paramedics,\npilot and 2 co-pilots -- now placed under quarantine -- who flew him\nfrom Nigeria were not adequately protected against risk of infection\nduring their flight to South Africa). The ProMED Moderator commented:\n'the Lassa fever outbreaks provide a unique opportunity for teams of\nhealth professions to work together to understand the epidemiology of\nLassa fever better when outbreaks occur.\n\n'We have recently made predictive risk maps of Lassa Fever in West\nAfrica using all available information on the location of past human\ncases, serological surveys of rodents, and environmental data derived\nfrom both satellites and ground-based measures of climate. (See:\n<http://www.plosntds.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pntd.0000388;jsessionid=A18CA8161C084054F4225595CF9E71CB>).\n\nThe disease occurs within high rainfall areas of West Africa, a\nsubset of the very much wider environmental range of its multimammate\nrat host, _Mastomys natalensis_, which extends into many biotic zones\nin West, Central, Eastern and Southern Africa. Maps in the\npublication may be used to identify high risk areas within which\nespecial care should be taken to avoid contact with rats, their urine\nand faeces. Travellers expecting to visit countries from which Lassa\nfever has been reported could also be given more precise information\nabout high risk zones within those countries. Such risk maps can be\nproduced from records of past outbreaks without necessarily fully\nunderstanding the epidemiology of the disease in question. The past\nis a useful, though never perfect, guide to the future. Our eventual\naim, however, is to translate the statistical analyses involved in\nrisk map production into a fuller biological understanding of\ncrucial, limiting environmental variables that should inform future\nepidemiological studies.\n\nRisk maps of the sort we have produced will be much improved by\nadding precise geographical locations of past and new disease\noutbreaks, and we encourage much clearer identification and reporting\nof the locations where infection is most likely to have taken place.\n\nLassa fever was in fact 1st described from NorthEast Nigeria, but\nvery few data-points in our database came from Nigeria because of a\nlack of clear reporting of past cases from that country. Controlling\ndiseases certainly involves teamwork of nurses, medics and\nclinicians, as these reports of Lassa outbreaks have shown. Such\nteams are used to working together. However, understanding diseases\ninvolves cross-disciplinary teams (medics, biologists, geographers,\nsociologists, etc.) which do not necessarily 'self-assemble'\nthemselves in quite the same way, and thus may require new\ninitiatives from those involved in national and global health.\n\n--\nElisabeth Fichet-Calvet, PhD\nEvolutionary Biology Group, Universiteit Antwerpen\nGroenenborgerlaan 171, B-2020 Antwerpen, Belgium\n<Elisabeth.Fichet-Calvet@ua.ac.be>\n<ecalvet@club-internet.fr>\nand,\nDavid J. Rogers, PhD\nProfessor of Ecology,\nOxford University,\nTALA Research Group,\nDept. of Zoology,\nSouth Parks Rd.,\nOxford OX1 3PS, UK.\n<david.rogers@zoo.ox.ac.uk>\n\n[Pro-MED-mail welcomes this opportunity to draw attention to the work\nof Drs Fichet-Calvet and Rogers, which has resulted in the production\nof Lassa fever risk maps. These maps indicate the strong influence of\nrainfall, and a lesser influence of temperature in defining high risk\nareas. LASSA FEVER, PREDICTIVE MAPS - WEST AFRICA\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["lassa fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "lassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "430572", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - Nigeria: (KE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=430572", "date": "2010-05-19 18:00:03", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA: (KEBBI)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 18 May 2010\nSource: Independent online, SAPA/AFP report [edited]\n<http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=86&art_id=nw20100518140143379C877858>\n\n\nA fresh outbreak of Lassa fever has killed 17 people and left dozens\ninfected in northern Nigeria's Kebbi State in the past month, a\nhealth official said on Tuesday [18 May 2010]. 'We have so far lost\n17 people to the Lassa fever outbreak, which started about 4 weeks\nago,' state chief epidemiologist Shehu Mohammed told AFP [Agence France-Press].\n\nLassa fever is an endemic acute viral haemorrhagic illness common in\nwest Africa, which is usually contracted through contact with\nrodents' excreta. 'Scores of people have been confirmed to have been\ninfected with the disease,' said Mohammed in a phone interview. He\nsaid the outbreak was recorded in 3 local districts, including the\nstate capital Birnin-Kebbi, the worst hit with 9 recorded deaths.\n\nMohammed said the World Health Organisation has roped in medical\nexperts from South Africa, Netherlands and Nigeria's commercial\ncentre Lagos to help tackle the outbreak. The disease, which causes\nfever, headache, difficulty in swallowing and can lead to infection\nof vital organs and death, is named after the town of Lassa in\nnorthern Nigeria's Borno State where it was 1st identified in 1969.\n\nIt occurs mainly in Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria and in Sierra Leone,\nwhere it claims roughly 200 lives each year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4 weeks\nduration that occurs in West Africa. Though 1st described in the\n1950s, the virus causing the disease was not identified until 1969.\nThe virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus\nfamily _Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea,\nLiberia, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria but probably exists in\nother West African countries as well.\n\nAbout 80 percent of human infections are asymptomatic; the remaining\ncases have severe multi-system disease, where the virus affects\nseveral organs in the body, such as the liver, spleen and kidneys.\nThe incubation period of Lassa fever ranges from 6-21 days. The onset\nof the disease is usually gradual, starting with fever, general\nweakness, and malaise. After a few days, headache, sore throat,\nmuscle pain, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, cough, and\nabdominal may follow. Severe cases may progress to show facial\nswelling, fluid in the lung cavity, bleeding from mouth, nose, vagina\nor gastrointestinal tract, and low blood pressure. Protein may be\nnoted in the urine. Shock, seizures, tremor, disorientation, and coma\nmay be seen in the late stages. Deafness occurs in 25 percent of\npatients of whom half recover some function after 1-3 months.\nTransient hair loss and gait disturbance may occur during recovery.\n\nLassa fever is a zoonotic disease. The animal reservoir of Lassa\nvirus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as the\n'multimammate rat.' _Mastomys_ infected with Lassa virus do not\nbecome ill, but they can shed the virus in their urine and faeces.\n(An image of a multimammate rat can be viewed at:\n<http://www15.bni-hamburg.de/bni/bni2/neu2/getfile.acgi?area=forschunggruppen&pid=21232>).\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups. Persons at greatest risk are\nthose living in rural areas where _Mastomys_ are usually found,\nespecially in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions.\nThere is no epidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread\nbetween humans. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both\ncommunity and health care settings.\n\nThe virology of Lassa fever infections has recently been reviewed by\nCharrel RN, de Lamballerie X; Vet Microbiol. 2010 Jan\n27;140(3-4):213-20. Epub 2009 Aug 28). 'To date, the International\nCommittee for Taxonomy of Viruses recognizes that the family\n_Arenaviridae_ contains a unique genus _Arenavirus_ that includes 22\nviral species. (There are 9 additional arenaviruses that either have\nbeen discovered recently, or which taxonomic status remains pending).\nArenaviruses have been classified according to their antigenic\nproperties into 2 groups, the Lassa-Lymphocytic choriomeningitis\n(LCM) serocomplex and the Tacaribe serocomplex, which has been\nfurther divided into 4 evolutionary lineages. Each arenavirus is more\nor less tightly associated with a mammal host. The distribution of\nthe host dictates the distribution of the virus. Humans may become\ninfected by arenaviruses through direct contact with infected\nrodents, including bites, or through inhalation of infectious rodent\nexcreta and secreta. Lassa, Junin, Machupo, Guanarito, and Sabia\nviruses are known to cause a severe hemorrhagic fever, in western\nAfrica, Argentina, Bolivia, Venezuela, and Brazil, respectively.\nInfection by LCM virus can result in acute central nervous system\ndisease, congenital malformations, and infection in organ\ntransplantation recipients. Detection of arenaviruses in their animal\nhost can be achieved by virus isolation, and has recently taken\nadvantage of PCR-based techniques.'\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria can be accessed\nat: <http://healthmap.org/r/007*>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 18 May 2010\n The disease, which causes\nfever, headache, difficulty in swallowing and can lead to infection\nof vital organs and death, is named after the town of Lassa in\nnorthern Nigeria's Borno State where it was 1st identified in 1969. Humans may become\ninfected by arenaviruses through direct contact with infected\nrodents, including bites, or through inhalation of infectious rodent\nexcreta and secreta. It is a\nviral haemorrhagic fever with symptoms that are similar to Marburg disease\nand malaria. Its initial symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, sore\nthroat, muscle pains, and a general feeling of weakness. 'Severe cases may\nprogress to show facial swelling, fluid in the lung cavity and bleeding\nfrom the mouth and nose,' explained Dr Rahman.\n\nHumans can contract Lassa fever from contact with infected animals. The\nbest known carrier of the Lassa virus is a rodent known as the multimammate\nrat (_Mastomys_ species) that is commonly found in West African countries.\nThe rats shed the virus in their bodily excretions. The virus can also be\nspread through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces, or other\nbodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation (WHO) there is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans. Their\nstatistics show that up to 500 000 cases of Lassa fever are diagnosed in\nWest Africa every year and the fatality rate among hospitalised patients\nvaries between one per cent and 15 per cent.\n\nIn addition, Dr Rahman said, the pilot, 2 co-pilots and 2 paramedics who\naccompanied the doctor on the flight from Nigeria had been placed under\nquarantine as a precautionary measure. Dr Rahman explained that special\nisolation precautions had been taken at Unitas hospital to contain the\ndisease and to protect health workers in the isolation wards who might be\nmost at risk. 'These include the wearing of special protective clothing\nsuch as masks, gloves and gowns and the sterilisation of equipment,' he said.\n\nDr Rahman said early diagnosis of the patient was proof of the quality\nlaboratory services in the country which were able to make an early and\ncorrect diagnosis of the disease. 'It is also testimony to the excellent\nrelationship between the public health and private sectors, the latter\nbeing responsible for transporting the patient,' he added.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The reports of deaths resulting from the epidemics of meningitis and Lassa\nfever in Nigeria have been alarming. The World Health Organization (WHO)\nsaid over 93 cases of the virus [infection] had been confirmed in the\ncapital Abuja and neighboring Nasarawa state since December [2008].\n\nAt the Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital in Edo state, confirmed\ncases rose by 60 percent from December 2008 to January 2009. 'That is\na major increase, and, furthermore, these are just the cases we hear\nabout in hospital,' Marguerite Lamunu, WHO Lassa fever expert, told\nIRIN. 'In reality, there will probably be many more cases and deaths\nin the community, plus the disease is spreading from state to state.'\n\nLassa fever is an acute viral hemorrhagic condition transmitted\nthrough contact with the urine or feces of rodents, especially rats\nand shrews. It was 1st discovered in 1969 in the town of Lassa in\nnorthern Nigeria's Borno state. Lassa fever can also be transmitted\nthrough direct contact with the bodily fluids and feces of an\ninfected person or through airborne particles, according to Osi-Ogbu.\n\n'We have an epidemic on our hands,' Ogugua Osi-Ogbu, head of Lassa\nfever prevention and care at the National Hospital in Abuja (NHA),\ntold IRIN. The disease, which has an incubation period of one to 3\nweeks, has become endemic in parts of West Africa, where it kills at\nleast 5000 people each year among 300 000 to 500 000 cases, according\nto WHO. The illness is especially severe late in pregnancy, killing\nthe fetus and/or the mother in more than 80 percent of cases.\n\nThe Nigerian Federal Ministry of Health has alerted all 36 state\nHealth Ministries, directing them to step up public awareness\ncampaigns on preventing Lassa fever. 'We have embarked on a rigorous\ncampaign on the radio to sensitize our people on the dangers of Lassa\nfever, how it is contracted and effective measures to avoid\ninfection,' Kano State Health Commissioner Aisha Isyaku Kiru told\nIRIN. 'We are specifically calling on the people to observe and\nimprove community hygiene through proper refuse disposal to\ndiscourage rats from taking refuge, and keeping food and drinking\nwater in containers not accessible to rats,' Kiru said.\n\nAccording to residents, many ethnic groups consume rodents,\nespecially rats, hedgehogs and badgers. Undergrowth is often burned\nto smoke out rodents for ''bush meat,' as it is known locally,\ndriving the animals to take shelter in homes, thereby increasing the\nrisk of Lassa fever infection. 'Rodents are a source of meat to many\nof our people and the government needs to ban their consumption to\neffectively contain Lassa fever spread,' said Bernard Ayorchia, a\nprivate medical doctor in the central Nigerian city of Makurdi.\n\nAnother hurdle in tackling Lassa in Nigeria is the lack of\nlaboratories. Only 2 facilities, in the southern states of Lagos and\nEdo, are equipped to diagnose the illness. Initial symptoms, which\ninclude headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhea and coughing, are similar to those of malaria,\nwhich can also make diagnosing Lassa fever difficult, according to\nthe WHO. Severe cases may progress to bleeding from the mouth, nose,\nvagina or gastrointestinal tract. In late stages, seizures, shock,\ntremors and coma can occur.\n\n'The government must urgently provide laboratories for diagnosing\nLassa fever in all parts of the country,' said NHA's Osi-Ogbu. 'Early\ndetection of the virus and a prompt response are key in saving the\nlife of an infected person.'\n\nWHO plans in the coming days to send an evaluation team to affected\nstates in Nigeria to assess the scale of the outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is clear from the reaction of the Nigerian healthcare authorities\nthat the epidemic of Lassa fever is continuing to spread, but its\ntrue extent is difficult to assess. The estimated figure of at least\n8 fatalities and 93 confirmed cases has not changed since the\nprevious report from Nigeria on 24 Feb 2009. It is stated also that\nthe epidemic is spreading beyond the Federal Capital Territory (FCT)\nand Nasarawa, but the other states now affected are not named. The\nemphasis of the report concerns rodent control, but it would be\nrelevant also to determine the extent of person-to-person\ntransmission of infection in the development of the epidemic and to\nprovide appropriate advice.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>,\nand a map of the states of Nigeria showing the locations of the FCT,\nin the center (red), the adjacent state of Nasarawa (orange), and Edo\nstate (in SW, red) is available at:\n<http://www.cladiya.com/07MNIAsite/images/nigeria-map-prov.gif>\n- Mod.CP/JW]", "summary": "\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>,\nand a map of the states of Nigeria showing the locations of the FCT,\nin the center (red), the adjacent state of Nasarawa (orange), and Edo\nstate (in SW, red) is available at:\n<http://www.cladiya.com/07MNIAsite/images/nigeria-map-prov.gif>\n- Mod. The disease has already\nclaimed 8 lives in 3 weeks, and over 93 cases have been confirmed.\n\nLassa fever is a very deadly disease that can spread quickly within a\nshort period of time. It initially has malaria type symptoms and so\nis easily mistaken for malaria and under-treated early. It is,\nhowever, very critical to catch it in the very early stages. This is\na highly contagious disease that is transmitted traditionally by rat\nurine/feces contamination of food, drink and household items/goods.\nIt is also transmitted via body fluids and appears to be airborne in\nthe current form in Abuja.\n\nSymptoms include fever, general fatigue and weakness, headache, sore\nthroat, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, cough, abdominal\npain, and red spots. In advanced/severe cases, it may lead to a\nswollen face, bleeding from orifices (eyes, mouth, nose, genitalia),\nlow blood pressure, etc.\n\nThe good news is that the necessary steps to curb the growing\nepidemic are being taken by the FCT Health & Human Services\nSecretariat, the Federal Ministry of Health and the World Health\nOrganization. So there is no need to panic.\n\nWash all foods; cook all meats thoroughly; store all drink in sealed\ncontainers; keep your house and surroundings as free as possible from\nanything that will attract and/or harbor rats. As soon as you suspect\nLassa fever, or if you have persistent fever that does not respond to\nstandard malaria treatment, report to the nearest FCT Health Centre.\nThe FCTA is setting up an emergency quarantine facility. Health Protection Agency, North East and North Central London\nHealth Protection Unit, London, United Kingdom\n2. Hospital for Tropical Diseases, University College London\nHospitals NHS Foundation Trust, London, United Kingdom\n3. Health Protection Agency, Gastrointestinal, Emerging and Zoonotic\nInfections (GEZI) Department, Centre for Infections, Colindale, United Kingdom\n4. Virus Reference Dept (VRD), Centre for Infections, Colindale,\nUnited Kingdom]\n\nIn February 2009, the 12th recorded case of Lassa fever, since\nsurveillance records are available, was imported to the United\nKingdom (UK). This is the 2nd case to be imported to the UK in 2009\nand the 1st reported case to have acquired infection in Mali. Risk\nassessment of 117 UK healthcare contacts with potential direct\nexposure to the patient's body fluids was undertaken. 7 contacts are\nconsidered to be at high risk of infection and are being actively\nmonitored for 21 days.\n\nBackground\n----------\nLassa fever is caused by an arenavirus and is an acute illness of\nbetween one and 3 weeks duration. The incubation period is usually 7\nto 12 days but may range between three and 21 days. About 80 percent\nof human infections in endemic areas are asymptomatic. The overall\ncase fatality rate is 1 percent, although it is reported to be 15\npercent-20 percent in hospitalised patients (1,2).\n\nThe natural host of Lassa virus is the multimammate rat (_Mastomys_\nspecies), which sheds the virus in urine and droppings. Transmission\nof the virus to humans usually occurs via direct or indirect contact\nwith rodent excreta. Person-to-person transmission occurs through\ndirect contact with blood, saliva, urine, faeces, or semen (1).\n\nLassa fever is known to be endemic in parts of West Africa, with most\ncases reported from Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Nigeria. People\nliving in rural areas of West Africa are most at risk of Lassa fever.\nImported cases to the UK are rare and occur almost exclusively in\nindividuals who have worked in endemic areas in high risk occupations\nsuch as medical or development workers (4). Although there is some\nevidence of endemicity in neighbouring countries (1,3-5), this is the\n1st case of imported Lassa fever from Mali into the UK.\n\nClinical case description\n-------------------------\nIn February 2009, a man in his 20s was admitted to University College\nHospital in London (UCLH) having been medically evacuated from Mali\nwith a 10-day history of fever and a diagnosis of falciparum malaria\nthat did not respond to treatment. He had been in a village in\nsouthern Mali for 4 weeks, where he was working in remote rural\nconditions on the border with the Ivory Coast. He had travelled\ndirectly from the UK to Bamako, Mali and then travelled overland to\nsouthern Mali. Although precise details of possible exposure to\nrodents are not known, rodents including rats were seen regularly in\nthe village.\n\nOn arrival the patient was alert and able to give a clear report on\nhis medical history. However, he deteriorated rapidly and was\ntransferred to a negative pressure room in the intensive care unit.\nHe died of multi-organ failure later the same day. His malaria blood\nfilm and rapid antigen test were negative and a diagnosis of Lassa\nfever was confirmed the same night by PCR.\n\nThe patient was originally considered at low risk of Lassa fever\nbecause the disease has never been reported in Mali and is thus not\nconsidered endemic there. However, as he became more unwell his\nstatus was upgraded. Standard universal infection control precautions\nwere followed and visors, but not full body protection, were worn\nduring the attempted resuscitation.\n\nVirological analysis\n--------------------\nThe diagnosis was confirmed in 2 different reverse transcription PCR\n(RT-PCR) assays targeting different regions of the genome and by\nsequencing of the 291 amino acids at the N-terminus of the Lassa\nvirus glycoprotein C (6). The detection of Lassa virus in 2 different\nRT-PCRs together with the characterisation of a unique part of the\nLassa virus genomic sequence constituted a definitive diagnosis.\nFurther studies including virus culture are in progress, and\nsequencing of the entire genome of the isolate is planned.\n\nPhylogenetic analysis showed that the virus was distinct from other\nLassa virus strains but grouped most closely with a strain of Lassa\nvirus (Lassa (AV)) isolated from a case reported from Germany in 2000\n(7) . The German patient had travelled through Ivory Coast, Ghana,\nand Burkina Faso during the incubation period and the investigations\ncould not determine where he had acquired the virus. The British case\nreported here had been working close to the border with Ivory Coast.\n[The original text is accompanied by a figure showing the\nphylogenetic relationship of the Mali virus with other African arenaviruses].\n\nSurveillance and management of contacts\n---------------------------------------\nAn Incident Control Team (ICT) meeting was called by UCLH early the\nfollowing day to discuss risk assessment of contacts, safe\ndecontamination of the environment, and management of the body. The\nICT identified 123 people who could have come into direct contact\nwith the Lassa virus either through contact with the case or exposure\nto body fluids. Almost all of these contacts were UCLH emergency care\nand laboratory staff. All UK based contacts were assigned to one of 3\ncategories depending upon their level of risk (no risk, low risk, or\nhigh risk, and were managed as reported recently (8). Contacts will\nbe monitored for 21 days from exposure.\n\nNone of the category 3 contacts received ribavirin prophylaxis. The\nevidence base for the use of ribavirin prophylaxis is limited, but\ncategory 3 contacts were given information explaining its possible\nbenefits and side effects and were left to make an informed choice.\n\nThe German air ambulance crew are being followed up and managed by\nGerman authorities, and the World Health Organization (WHO) is\nsupporting health authorities in Mali in conducting field\ninvestigations and in the implementation of control measures.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nIn the case described here, the reported diagnosis of malaria and the\nfact that Mali has not been considered endemic for Lassa fever made\nthe clinical diagnosis difficult. As a consequence, the initial risk\nof Lassa fever was considered low. Only when the patient developed\nmulti-organ failure 6 hours after admission was the risk of Lassa\nfever upgraded. Universal barrier precautions were used throughout,\nbut not the high levels of protection currently recommended for viral\nhaemorrhagic fevers (9). As a result, 76 hospital staff were put at\nrisk in the space of 8 hours, and 3 of 7 category 3 contacts were\nlaboratory staff. Although transmission to healthcare workers from\nimported Lassa fever cases is very rare, this can cause considerable\nanxiety among contacts. There is only one reported case of\ntransmission in a hospital setting in an industrialised country, and\nthis was a seroconversion without clinical illness in Germany (10).\n\nThis is the 1st Lassa virus to be characterised from Mali. The virus\nis closely related to isolates from neighbouring countries and was\namplified using a widely used diagnostic PCR test (6). There is\nserological evidence that Lassa virus is present in Mali (3,5), but\nthis is the 1st proven imported case and has implications for current\nrisk assessment in travellers returning from this area.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. The animal reservoirs of Lassa\nvirus are rodents of the genus _Mastomys_, the 'multimammate rat.'\nLassa virus-infected animals do not become ill, but they can shed the\nvirus in their urine and faeces. (A photograph of a multimammate rat\ncan be accessed at\n<http://i127.photobucket.com/albums/p145/hawthornrats/other%20pets/multis/DSCF4892.jpg>).\n\nIn humans Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4\nweeks duration that occurs in West Africa. It has\nbeen estimated that about 300 000 to 500 000 cases of Lassa fever and\n5000 deaths occur yearly across West Africa. The overall\ncase-fatality rate is 1 percent, and up to 15 percent among\nhospitalized patients.\n\nThe disease is especially severe late in pregnancy, with maternal\ndeath and/or fetal loss occurring in greater than 80 percent of cases\nduring the 3rd trimester.\n\nHumans usually become infected with Lassa virus from exposure to\nexcreta of infected _Mastomys_. Lassa virus may also be spread\nbetween humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces,\nor other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. There is no\nepidemiological evidence supporting airborne spread between humans.\nPerson-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical\nequipment, such as re-used needles.\n\nThe current increase in cases of Lassa fever in some parts of Nigeria\nmay by a consequence of increased abundance of the vector or some\nother factor resulting in increased contact between humans and\nrodents promoting the spread of the disease in the human population. - Mod.CP\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 16 Feb 2009\n \n\nProf Akpede, who spoke at National Lassa Fever Stakeholders Forum at\nEkpoma [at the] weekend [14-15 Feb 2009] noted that there had been a\nmarked rise in the number of suspected and confirmed cases between\nDecember 2008 and January 2009 representing about 60 percent and 80\npercent increases respectively. \n\nIn his contribution, [the] member representing Esan Central/Esan\nWest/Igueben Federal Constituency in the House of Representatives,\nMr. Patrick Ikhariale, also expressed concern over the spread of the\nLassa fever epidemic nation-wide and called for urgent control\nmeasures at the national level.
