Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Lassa fever is a zoonotic disease, whereby humans become infected\nfrom contact with infected animals. \n\nThe disease is especially severe late in pregnancy, with maternal\ndeath and/or fetal loss occurring in greater than 80 percent of cases\nduring the 3rd trimester. Lassa virus may also be spread\nbetween humans through direct contact with the blood, urine, faeces,\nor other bodily secretions of a person with Lassa fever. The virus is a\nsingle-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus family\n_Arenaviridae_. Person-to-person transmission occurs in both community and health\ncare settings, where the virus may be spread by contaminated medical\nequipment, such as re-used needles.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "lassa fever"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever"], "event_date": ["2009-01-25 00:00:00", "2008-12-25 00:00:00", "2009-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hamburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "lassa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "151642", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - UK ex Nigeria (03): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=151642", "date": "2009-01-30 18:00:48", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - UNITED KINGDOM ex NIGERIA (03): FATAL\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 29 Jan 2009\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/7859655.stm>\n\n\nA 66-year-old man being treated in hospital for Lassa fever has died\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe patient, from east London, died following a sudden deterioration\nin his condition, said a spokesman from Hampstead's Royal Free\nHospital. The man, who has not been identified, had been travelling\nin Nigeria and was admitted to hospital soon after returning to the\nUK on 6 Jan 2009. Lassa fever was diagnosed on 22 Jan 2009 at the\nHospital for Tropical Diseases. Next of kin have been informed. A\nspokeswoman from the Health Protection Agency (HPA) said there was no\nrisk of contamination to the public.\n\nLassa fever is caused by the Lassa virus and is endemic in Nigeria,\nSierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and the Central African Republic.\nHundreds of thousands of people are infected in these countries each\nyear and isolated cases have been seen in Europe and the USA. Around 8\nin 10 people infected with Lassa virus develop mild or no symptoms,\nbut in 20 percent of cases people will have severe illness. Symptoms\ninclude fever, headache, sore throat, a cough, nausea, vomiting,\ndiarrhoea, and muscle pain. A common complication is deafness, but\nonly about 2 percent of all patients die from the illness.\n\nDr Dilys Morgan, a Lassa fever expert at the HPA, said: 'This is an\nisolated case. It is important to stress that there is no risk to the\ngeneral public from this patient. 'Lassa fever is an infection that is\nfound in West Africa and is seen rarely in this country in those who\nhave travelled to parts of the world where it is common. The virus is\nspread by infected rats through their urine and droppings. The\ninfection is not easily spread to others and then only by direct\ncontact with bodily fluids.'\n\nThere have been 10 confirmed cases of Lassa fever in the UK since 1970.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Detailed information concerning Lassa fever can be obtained from the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) website at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html>.\n\nA photograph of the multimammate rat, the vector of the disease in\nWest Africa, can be accessed at\n<http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2277/1519984565_7d4acc91c9.jpg?v=0>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 29 Jan 2009\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-Lan Banks\n\n[Detailed information concerning Lassa fever can be obtained from the\nWorld Health Organisation (WHO) website at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html>. Subsequently,\nthe Ebonyi state government has declared that since Lassa fever virus\nis being carried by a special type of rat that is common in West\nAfrica, the state's ministry of health has decided to carry out\nenlightenment campaigns against bush burning and rat hunting for\nconsumption.\n\nCommissioner for Health in the state, Dr Sunday Nwangene said: 'In\nfact we shall be encouraging people to kill all rats in their houses;\nmy environmental officers will go about rat decapitation and\nfumigation of possible environments like the teaching hospital has\njust done.'\n\nNwangene stated that government's reaction was sparked off by the\nsudden death of a medical doctor in his prime, early this month\n[March 2008], at EBSUTH where a similar death was recorded on 23 Jan\n[2008].\n\nSpeaking in a statewide sensitization campaign for health workers,\nthe health commissioner said: 'It is quite proper to inform you of\nthe reason for your gathering this noon...it is simply because of an\noutbreak of a disease threatening the precious lives of everyone\nincluding you since January this year [2008] and appears to have\nsummoned more courage in its severity of morbidity and frightening\nmortality.' The\npatient travelled in Nigeria before returning to the United Kingdom\n(UK) and is now being treated at the high security infectious\ndiseases unit at the Royal Free Hospital in north London. The Health\nProtection Agency (HPA) said the patient, whose gender is not being\ndisclosed, represented an isolated case and there was no risk to the\ngeneral public.\n\nLassa fever is caused by Lassa virus and is endemic in Nigeria,\nSierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea and the Central African Republic.\nHundreds of thousands of people are infected in these countries each\nyear and isolated cases have been seen in Europe and the US [imported\nfrom Africa - Mod.CP]. Infection also occurs in other African\ncountries including Mali, Senegal and the Democratic Republic of Congo.\n\nAround 8 in 10 people infected with Lassa virus develop mild or no\nsymptoms, but in 20 percent of cases people will have severe illness.\nSymptoms include fever, headache, sore throat, a cough, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhoea and muscle pain. Around 2 percent of all patients\ndie from the illness and death rates are particularly high in women\nin the final months of pregnancy. A common complication of Lassa\nfever is deafness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa viral haemorrhagic fever is an acute illness of 1-4 weeks\nduration that occurs in West Africa. Though 1st described in the\n1950s, the virus causing the disease was not identified until 1969.\nThe virus is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the virus\nfamily _Arenaviridae_. Lassa fever is known to be endemic in Guinea\n(Conakry), Liberia, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria, but probably\nin other West African countries as well.\n\nLassa fever is a zoonotic disease, meaning that humans become\ninfected from contact with infected animals. The animal reservoir of\nLassa virus is a rodent of the genus _Mastomys_, commonly known as\nthe 'multimammate rat.' Mastomys infected with Lassa virus do not\nbecome ill, but they can shed the virus in their excreta (urine and faeces).\n\nLassa fever occurs in all age groups and in both men and women.\nPersons at greatest risk are those living in rural areas where\nMastomys are usually found, especially in areas of poor sanitation or\ncrowded living conditions. Health care workers are at risk if proper\nbarrier nursing and infection control practices are not maintained.\n\nFamily members and health care workers should always be careful to\navoid contact with blood and body fluids while caring for sick\npersons. Routine barrier nursing precautions probably protect against\ntransmission of Lassa virus in most circumstances. However, for added\nsafety, patients suspected to have Lassa fever should be cared for\nunder specific 'isolation precautions,' which include the wearing of\nprotective clothing such as masks, gloves, gowns, and face shields,\nand the systematic sterilization of contaminated equipment. The\nantiviral drug ribavirin is effective treatment for Lassa fever if\ngiven early on in the course of clinical illness.\n\nFurther information can be obtained from the World Health\nOrganisation Web site at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs179/en/index.html>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[A map showing the countries in West Africa mentioned above is\navailable at:\n<http://everythingspossible.files.wordpress.com/2008/03/map-west-africa.jpg>\n- Copyed.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 23 Jan 2009\n However, for added\nsafety, patients suspected to have Lassa fever should be cared for\nunder specific 'isolation precautions,' which include the wearing of\nprotective clothing such as masks, gloves, gowns, and face shields,\nand the systematic sterilization of contaminated equipment. Minister of State for Health,\nMr. Gabriel Aduku, said the spread and impact of the sickness needed\nto be checked to forestall a situation in which it would overwhelm\nthe population in the near future.\n\nAduku, who spoke at a media sensitization workshop to herald the\nRegional Conference on Lassa Fever due to be held this week, said\nalthough the Federal Ministry of Health has made some efforts and\nsigned a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Chinese\ngovernment in 2004, there was an urgent need to step up efforts in\nthe area. This, he said, would ensure a steady supply of drugs for\ntreatment of the ailment, provision of functional laboratory\nservices, as well as the development of an effective and affordable\nvaccine for Lassa fever.\n\nHe recalled that some years ago, the Federal Ministry of Health\ndesignated 3 federal tertiary health institutions as centres of\nexcellence for the control and management of the disease. According\nto Aduku, the 3 centres -- namely the Irrua Specialist Teaching\nHospital, Edo State, University of Maiduguri Teaching Hospital, Borno\nState, and the Federal Medical Centre, Owerri, Imo State -- needed to\nbe strengthened through an update of their facilities to contain the\ndisease. He, however, assured the Lassa Fever Stakeholders Forum, the\nconveners of the regional conference, of the government's continued\nsupport in the task of combating Lassa fever in the country.\n\nChief Medical Director of the Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital,\nProfessor Godwin Akpede, disclosed that the conference is aimed at\ndeveloping capacity towards containing the challenge of the epidemic\nin the West African sub-region; delineating the constraints against\nsuccess in the efforts to reduce the prevalence, incidence and\nmortality arising from the disease; and developing strategies for the\ncontrol and eradication of the disease.\n\nLassa fever was 1st encountered in the 1950s, and the virus was\nidentified in 1969. The virus is named after Lassa, the town in Borno\nState, North Eastern Nigeria, where the 1st case of the disease\noccurred. Since then, some states in Nigeria, such as Edo, Borno,\nNasarawa, Plateau, Ebonyi and Imo, have suffered ravages of the epidemic.\n\nIt is endemic to Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia. The\ndisease is said to be spread by rats, which are, however, found\nthroughout West Africa. Therefore, the actual geographic range of the\ndisease may be more extensive. Evidence of the infection has also\nbeen found in the Central African Republic, Congo, Mali and Senegal.\n\n[Byline: Onwuka Nzeshi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lassa fever was 1st described in the 1950s, although the virus\n(_Lassa virus_, family _ Arenaviridae_, genus _Arenavirus_) was not\nisolated until 1969. The disease occurs in West Africa and is\ntransmitted to humans from wild rodents through direct or indirect\ncontact with the excreta of infected animals. Person-to-person and\nlaboratory infections occur, particularly in the hospital\nenvironment, by direct contact with blood or other body fluids of patients.\n\nThe onset of disease is gradual, with fever, vomiting and\nretrosternal pain. Signs may include conjunctival infection,\nperiorbital edema and swelling of the neck. Deafness occurs in 25\npercent of all patients. In severe cases, patients suffer shock,\nfluid in the lung cavity, haemorrhage and cerebral edema.\nApproximately 15 percent of hospitalized patients die, but the\noutcome can be improved by simple supportive care if provided early\nin the course of the disease. Specific treatment with the antiviral\ndrug ribavirin may also be effective.\n\nThe signs and symptoms of Lassa fever may be difficult to distinguish\nfrom severe malaria, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral\nhaemorrhagic fevers, but definitive diagnosis requires confirmation\nby laboratory testing. Health education strategies for preventing\ninfections in people living in endemic areas focus on rodent control\nand minimizing contact with rodent excreta. Measures to control virus\ntransmission from cases include routine use of standard precautions,\nisolation of suspected cases and surveillance of contacts.\n\nLassa fever is endemic in several West African countries. According\nto the WHO as well as Nigeria, the most severely affected countries\nare Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Cote d'Ivoire, and Ghana. The\nincidence of Lassa fever has been increasing in all areas,\nparticularly in regions of social and political strife.\n\nA map of the provinces of Nigeria can be accessed at\n<http://www.ngex.com/nigeria/places/default.htm>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[For the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map providing links to\nProMED-mail postings on events occurring in surrounding countries as\nwell as within Nigeria, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=9.6,8.1,5>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\nChief Medical Director of the Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital,\nProfessor Godwin Akpede, disclosed that the conference is aimed at\ndeveloping capacity towards containing the challenge of the epidemic\nin the West African sub-region; delineating the constraints against\nsuccess in the efforts to reduce the prevalence, incidence and\nmortality arising from the disease; and developing strategies for the\ncontrol and eradication of the disease. \n\nAduku, who spoke at a media sensitization workshop to herald the\nRegional Conference on Lassa Fever due to be held this week, said\nalthough the Federal Ministry of Health has made some efforts and\nsigned a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Chinese\ngovernment in 2004, there was an urgent need to step up efforts in\nthe area. Cases in humans occur\nsporadically, as in this situation. - Mod.TY]\nLiberia, which experienced a devastating 14-year civil war that ended\nin 2003, last registered Lassa fever outbreaks in September [2006],\nmostly in Nimba County. Health officials said at the time they did\nnot have the capacity to diagnose or treat the deadly disease but the\noutbreak ended after the Chinese Embassy stepped in with funds for\nmedicines and testing kits.\nMildred Wesseh, a Ministry of Health spokesperson, told the\nIntegrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) on Wednesday [11 Apr\n2007] that the ministry has now confirmed a further 13 cases in Nimba\nCounty, close to the border with Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire. Cases have\nalso been reported in Bong County (central Liberia) and Lofa (north),\naccording to the Health Ministry.\n'We are very concerned about the active circulation of Lassa fever\n[virus] and are now putting in place mechanisms to deal with the\ndisease, especially in the affected areas,' Wesseh said.\nShe said 5 people suspected of having the disease died, but health\nauthorities had not confirmed whether the cause of death was Lassa.\nSome 21 suspected cases have been reported but only 13 were\nconfirmed, and those who were currently infected with Lassa [virus]\nwere being given medication, she said.\nLassa is a viral haemorrhagic fever known to be endemic in Liberia,\nGuinea, Sierra Leone and parts of Nigeria. It probably exists in\nother West African countries as well, according to the World Health\nOrganisation (WHO).\nHumans become infected with Lassa from contact with infected rodents.\nThe virus can also be transmitted from one human to another through\ndirect contact with body fluids. Rural dwellers, especially those\nliving in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions, are\nat greatest risk of contracting the illness, WHO says.\nAccording to Liberia's Human Development Report (2006), by the end of\nthe country's civil war 95 percent of health facilities had been\ndestroyed and just 20 trained Liberian doctors were left in the\ncountry, while the United Nations children's agency (UNICEF)\nestimated in September 2006 that just 7 percent of people in rural\nareas have access to clean drinking water.\nThe UN this week appealed for an additional USD 117 million in donor\nassistance for Liberia to help rebuild basic social services. It\nestimated that 70 percent of health facilities in the country were\nstill being run by international nongovernmental organisations.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The tragic effects that civil war can have on health services, with\nthe resulting difficulty that public health officials in controlling\noutbreaks and treating infected patients, is vividly illustrated in\nthis situation. A Lassa fever epidemic during 2004 claimed [the lives\nof] more than 22 persons in the area.\nA doctor who spoke with Vanguard regarding the incident in Ekpoma assured\nthat much is being done by the students and the community to educate the\nresidents on the causes of the deadly disease and methods of control. 'We are\nworried, but we are doing well in the area of control. We made [the\npopulation] understand that Lassa fever has an incubation period of 6-21 days\nand is transmitted from wild rodents through direct or indirect contact with\nexcreta of infected rodents.'\nContacted regarding the death of the 2 students at AAU, the Director of\nInformation, Protocol and Public Affairs Dr. Don Akhailomen confirmed the\nexistence of an outbreak of Lassa fever, but said they have not received any\nreport on the death of any students.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A similar report mentioning 13 deaths has been received from Joe Shea,\nEditor-in-Chief of The American Reporter. Lassa fever is a zoonosis, with\ninfection being acquired from _Mastomys natalensis_, the multimammate rat.\nThe disease is endemic in west Africa. Lassa virus belongs to the old-world\ngroup of arenaviruses. Like all arenaviruses, these viruses cause persistent\ninfections of rodents (_Mastomys_ sp. in the case of Lassa virus), usually\nwithout obvious signs of disease.\nHumans and other animals are infected through contact with rodent excreta,\nparticularly urine. Cases of Lassa fever are limited to West Africa and have\nbeen reported most frequently from Sierra Leone, and to a lesser extent from\nNigeria, Liberia, and Guinea. In endemic areas of rural West Africa,\nsubclinical infection is common, but occasional outbreaks with high mortality\nrates have been recorded. - Mod.CP]\n[Note that there have been some cases in Europe coming from Africa -- see\nrefs below -- but there were no secondary cases in other passengers on the\nsame flights or in hospital staff. - Mod,JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The outbreak of Lassa fever, according to health sources close to the Irrua\nSpecialist Hospital (ISTH), was noticed by doctors at the hospital following\nlaboratory analysis conducted after repeated cases of unusual symptoms\ninitially diagnosed as mere fever. On 10\nFeb 2007 he was admitted to the National Hospital Abuja, where he\npresented with abdominal tenderness and fever; mildly elevated liver\nenzymes; leucopenia and thrombocytopenia were also noted. Malaria and\nviral hepatitis were ruled out. He became afebrile after 4 days of\nantibiotic treatment, but on 15 Feb [2007] presented with vomiting,\ngeneralized tonic-clonic convulsion, petechial hemorrhages on upper\ntrunk, bleeding from vena puncture sites, and confusion. Two days\nlater due to renal failure he was treated with emergency\nhemodialysis. On 19 Feb[2007] he was medically evacuated from Nigeria\nto a hospital in Pretoria, South Africa. Lassa fever was suspected,\nand blood specimens were sent to the Special Pathogens Unit of the\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases on 20 Feb 2007, where\nLassa virus infection was confirmed by RT-PCR (reverse transcription\npolymerase chain reaction) and serology.\nTransmission of Lassa virus from its natural rodent reservoir to\nhumans can cause hemorrhagic fever syndrome, which is associated with\nhigh death rates. Lassa fever is endemic in West Africa and has been\nreported from Sierra Leone, Guinea, Liberia, and Nigeria. Only a few\ncases of importation of Lassa virus into other regions have been\ndocumented worldwide. Although importation of a Lassa fever case\nraises public concern because of the possibility of human-to-human\ntransmission and lack of an effective and safe therapy, the actual\nrisk for infection spread from an imported case appears to be low.\nThe Lassa fever patient admitted to a hospital in Pretoria is\ncurrently being treated in isolation. He is ill, but stable. South\nAfrican health authorities have taken all necessary measures to\nprevent transmission of the virus. Medical personnel in contact with\nthe patient are under observation although no specific incidents\nconstituting overt exposure to infection have been recorded. Medical\nauthorities in Nigeria and WHO have been informed of the case.\n--\nJanusz T. Paweska, DVSc., Dr. hab.\nHead Special Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases\nof the National Health Laboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\nModderfontein Road 1\nGauteng, South Africa\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>\n[Excerpts from the US CDC Special Pathogens Branch fact sheet on\nLassa Fever\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/lassaf.htm>\nprovide the following information [edited]:\n'In areas of Africa where the disease is endemic (that is, constantly\npresent), Lassa fever is a significant cause of morbidity and\nmortality. While Lassa fever is mild or has no observable symptoms in\nabout 80 percent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20\npercent have a severe multisystem disease. Lassa fever is also\nassociated with occasional epidemics, during which the case-fatality\nrate can reach 50 percent.\n'Lassa fever is an endemic disease in portions of West Africa. It is\nrecognized in Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, as well as Nigeria.\nHowever, because the rodent species that carry the virus are found\nthroughout West Africa, the actual geographic range of the disease\nmay extend to other countries in the region.\n'The number of Lassa virus infections per year in West Africa is\nestimated at 100 000 to 300 000, with approximately 5000 deaths.\nUnfortunately, such estimates are crude, because surveillance for\ncases of the disease is not uniformly performed. In some areas of\nSierra Leone and Liberia, it is known that 10-16 percent of people\nadmitted to hospitals have Lassa fever, which indicates the serious\nimpact of the disease on the population of this region.'\nRodents in the genus _Mastomys_ are the reservoir hosts, and an image\ncan be seen at:\n<http://www.fieldmuseum.org/congo/images/mammals/mastomys.jpg> - Mod.TY]\n[A map showing Jalingo and the Taraba State in Nigeria can be accessed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Head Special Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases\nof the National Health Laboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\n Lassa fever was suspected,\nand blood specimens were sent to the Special Pathogens Unit of the\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases on 20 Feb 2007, where\nLassa virus infection was confirmed by RT-PCR (reverse transcription\npolymerase chain reaction) and serology. The disease occurs in West Africa, and is transmitted\nto humans from wild rodents, through direct or indirect contact with the\nexcreta of infected animals. Person-to-person and laboratory infections\noccur, particularly in the hospital environment, by direct contact with\nblood or other body fluids of patients. The onset of disease is gradual,\nwith fever, vomiting and retrosternal pain. Signs may include conjunctival\ninjection, periorbital edema and swelling of the neck. Deafness occurs in\n25 percent of all patients. In severe cases, patients suffer shock, fluid\nin the lung cavity, haemorrhage and cerebral edema. Approximately 15\npercent of hospitalized patients die, but the outcome can be improved by\nsimple supportive care if provided early in the course of the disease.\nSpecific treatment with the antiviral drug ribavirin may also be effective.\nThe signs and symptoms of Lassa fever may be difficult to distinguish from\nsevere malaria, typhoid fever, yellow fever and other viral haemorrhagic\nfevers, but diagnosis can be assisted with simple laboratory support.\nDefinitive diagnosis requires testing that is available only in highly\nspecialized laboratories. Health education strategies for preventing\ninfections in people living in endemic areas focus on rodent control and\nminimizing contact with rodent excreta. Measures to control virus\ntransmission from cases include routine use of standard precautions,\nisolation of suspected cases and surveillance of contacts.\nLassa fever is endemic in several West African countries. The most severely\naffected countries are in the Mano River Union (Guinea, Liberia and Sierra\nLeone) and Nigeria. Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana are potentially at risk. The\nincidence of Lassa fever has been increasing in the affected areas. Civil\nunrest in the Mano River Union region created newly vulnerable populations,\nincluding refugees and humanitarian relief workers. There have been several\nrecent fatal cases of Lassa fever among United Nations peacekeeping forces.\nThe return of areas to government control and the rebuilding of civil\nsociety in Liberia and Sierra Leone puts aid workers at risk of contracting\nLassa fever.\nNosocomial outbreak \ufffd Kenema, Sierra Leone, 2004\n------------------------------------------------\nThe Kenema Government Hospital, Sierra Leone, reported an outbreak of Lassa\nfever in the winter of 2004, affecting patients from the paediatric ward,\nand claiming the lives of several health-care workers. The majority of\ncases occurred in young children, many of whom were referred directly from\nthe paediatric ward, a pattern not previously observed. WHO sent a field\ninvestigation team to Kenema to assist Ministry of Health and Sanitation\nofficials in assessing the situation and containing further spread. Between\n1 Jan and 24 Apr 2004, 95 paediatric cases were admitted, 78 percent of\nwhom were patients referred from the paediatric ward to the Lassa ward,\ncompared with only 17 percent in 2003. The mean age of cases was 18 years,\nwith half of all cases aged under 15 years; 50 percent were female. The\ncase-fatality rate was 30-50 percent in children aged under 5 years and 71\npercent in children aged under 1 year.\nThe large number of cases discharged from the paediatric ward in a\nsatisfactory condition and then readmitted for Lassa fever infection within\ndays to several weeks pointed to nosocomial transmission in the paediatric\nward. The most likely cause was parenteral drug administration from\ncontaminated multidose vials. Sharing of contaminated needles and syringes\ncould also not be ruled out. Following implementation of infection control\nmeasures, the outbreak abated.\nMano River Union Lassa fever network\n------------------------------------\nRecent peace initiatives have opened new opportunities to combat Lassa\nfever. The Office of United States Foreign Disaster Assistance, United\nNations peacekeeping forces, the European Union, national and\nnongovernmental organizations, as well as WHO have joined forces to\nestablish the Mano River Union Lassa fever network. This programme will\nassist Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone to develop national prevention\nstrategies and enhance laboratory diagnostics, clinical management and\nenvironmental control of Lassa fever. In addition, a new ward dedicated to\nthe care of patients with Lassa fever, sponsored by the European Union, is\nunder construction at Kenema Government Hospital.\nOn rare occasions, travellers arriving from areas where Lassa fever is\nendemic export the disease to other countries. Although malaria, typhoid\nfever, yellow fever and many other tropical infections are much more\ncommon, the diagnosis of Lassa fever should be considered in febrile\npatients returning from West Africa, especially if they have had exposures\nin rural areas or hospitals in countries where Lassa fever is known to be\nendemic. Health workers attending a patient suspected of having Lassa fever\nshould immediately contact local and national experts for advice and to\narrange for laboratory testing.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Although malaria, typhoid\nfever, yellow fever and many other tropical infections are much more\ncommon, the diagnosis of Lassa fever should be considered in febrile\npatients returning from West Africa, especially if they have had exposures\nin rural areas or hospitals in countries where Lassa fever is known to be\nendemic. It probably exists in\nother West African countries as well, according to the UN World\nHealth Organisation (WHO).\nHumans become infected with Lassa from contact with infected rodents.\nThe virus can also be transmitted from one human to another through\ndirect contact with body fluids. Rural dwellers, especially those\nliving in areas of poor sanitation or crowded living conditions, are\nat greatest risk of contracting the illness.\nSymptoms include headache, sore throat, muscle pain, chest pain,\nnausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and cough. Severe cases may progress to\nbleeding from the mouth, nose, vagina or gastrointestinal tract.\nWHO says some studies indicate that 300 000 to 500 000 cases of Lassa\nfever and 5000 deaths occur yearly across West Africa. The overall\ncase-fatality rate is 1 percent to 15 percent among hospitalised\npatients, WHO says. The illness is especially severe late in\npregnancy, with fetal loss and sometimes maternal death occurring in\nmore than 80 percent of cases.\nPewu said rural health workers in Nimba County do not have the\ncapacity to deal with the disease. 'The drugs for treatment for Lassa\nfever are in short supply,' he said.\nThe humanitarian coordination section of the UN Mission in Liberia\n(UNMIL) in its situation report early this week noted the poor state\nof health infrastructure to deal with the illness.\n'Some of the problems in tackling the disease include weak or\nnon-existent surveillance, monitoring and supervision, poor diagnosis\nof the disease at some health facilities, and lack of adequate drugs\nand treatment facilities,' the report said.\nThe report, which quoted a joint team of the Ministry of Health and\nWHO that visited villages in Nimba County, said 'there is a high\npresence of Lassa fever' in those areas.\nLiberia's recent National Human Development Report said the country's\nhealth facilities were in ruins. It said the country's 14-year civil\nwar destroyed 95 percent of health facilities, and that the number of\ntrained government doctors in the country had dropped from 400 to\nless then 20 at the war's end in 2003.\n--\nDan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n[Borrowing from my colleague Mod. CP's comments in Lassa fever -\nNigeria (edo) 20050303.0654 'The disease is endemic in west Africa.\nLassa virus belongs to the old-world group of arenaviruses. Like all\narenaviruses, these viruses cause persistent infections of rodents\n(_Mastomys_ sp. in the case of Lassa virus), usually without obvious\nsigns of disease.\nHumans and other animals are infected through contact with rodent\nexcreta, particularly urine. Cases of Lassa fever are limited to West\nAfrica and have been reported most frequently from Sierra Leone, and\nto a lesser extent from Nigeria, Liberia, and Guinea. In endemic\nareas of rural West Africa, subclinical infection is common, but\noccasional outbreaks with high mortality rates have been recorded. - Mod.CP'.\nAs mentioned in the above newswire, information from the CDC fact\nsheet on Lassa fever: 'The number of Lassa virus infections per year\nin West Africa is estimated at 100 000 to 300 000, with approximately\n5000 deaths. On 5 Jul 2006, he developed high\nfever and his neurological symptoms worsened. On 10 Jul 2006, the\npatient traveled by air from Freetown (Sierra Leone) via Abijian\n(Ivory Coast) to Brussels, Belgium. All of this journey was in the\nsame airplane. In Brussels, the patient changed planes for the\nconnecting flight to Frankfurt, where he arrived on 11 Jul 2006. [The\nprogressive neurologic deterioration was most likely another disease\nprocess that the patient was undergoing and should not be interpreted\nas a 'chronic infection' with Lassa fever virus infection. One can't\nhelp but wonder if his exposure to the Lassa fever virus was\niatrogenic during health care provided for the progressive neurologic\ndeterioration. - Mod.MPP]\nImmediately after arriving, he was taken to the university hospital\nin Munster. On 16 Jul 2006, the patient's condition worsened, and he\nwas intubated and treated in isolation. Although the patient's\nclinical presentation was in accordance with his known underlying\ndisease, additional tests for tropical infectious diseases were\ncarried out. On 20 Jul 2006, IgG for Lassa virus was detected in a\ncerebrospinal fluid sample and reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain\nreaction (RT-PCR) was positive. On 21 Jul 2006, an RNA-PCR for Lassa\nvirus was detected in blood, urine and sputum.\nA message was posted on the confidential European Early warning and\nResponse System on Fri 21 Jul 2006. Human-to-human Lassa fever virus transmission has been mainly a\nhospital problem when medical staff, other patient care-givers, and persons\n(especially family members) in intimate contact with Lassa fever patients have\nbeen directly exposed to blood and other bodily fluids, usually in the absence\nof barrier nursing. Early in the initial Nigerian epidemic, a nurse infected\nand ill with Lassa fever virus traveled from Nigeria to New York by air\nwithout transmission of the virus to other passengers or the airline crew. In\nstudies conducted in the 1960s and 1970s, there was no evidence of Lassa fever\nvirus transmission to airline passengers traveling with confirmed Lassa fever\ncases (1). Similarly, in 2004, 19 passengers on a flight from London to\nNewark, New Jersey, USA, with a Lassa fever virus-infected man returning from\nLiberia, were considered at low risk of exposure, and none became infected\nwith the virus -- see ProMED ref. below. While awareness is indicated, care\nshould be taken not to engender fear among the passengers.\nReference:\n1. Galbraith NS, Berrie JRH, Forbes P, Young S. Public Health aspects of viral\nhaemorrhagic fevers in Britain. UK ex West Africa (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206619", "date": "2004-09-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER - UK EX WEST AFRICA (02)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 23 Sep 2004\nFrom: <Gahavisuka@aol.com>\nSource: Health Protection Agency, CDR Weekly, Vol 14, No.3, Thu 23 Sep 2004\n[edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/cdr/pages/news.htm#lassa>\n\nUK: probable Lassa fever in traveller returning from West Africa\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nPreliminary tests performed on Tue 14 Sep 2004 at the Health Protection\nAgency (HPA), Colindale, indicated Lassa fever virus infection in a patient\nwho has returned to the United Kingdom (UK) from West Africa. Confirmatory\ntests are in progress, together with virus isolation.\nThe patient had travelled in west Africa (Ivory Coast and Chad) for a month\nbefore returning to the UK on Thu 9 Sep 2004. He became unwell the next day\nwith fever, and attended his local Accident and Emergency Department 2 days\nlater. He was admitted in the early morning of 13 Sep 2004 and when the\ndiagnosis was suspected to be Lassa fever, he was transferred to\nmedium-secure facilities. After initial tests suggested Lassa fever, he was\nstarted on ribavirin treatment and transferred to high-security infectious\ndisease facilities. He remained well with a low-grade fever and remained\nhaemodynamically stable. He was discharged from hospital after tests were\npersistently negative and he had been apyrexial for 3 days.\nContacts are being followed up for 21 days, although all are considered to\nbe low risk. Staff who cared for the patient, handled his specimens or\notherwise had contact, visitors of the patient, and other community\ncontacts are being monitored through recording daily temperatures,\nfollowing guidance in the 1996 memorandum (1). Possible non-hospital\ncontacts have been assessed as low risk, and are self-monitoring their\ntemperature. As he was well and asymptomatic at the time of his travel, and\nLassa fever patients are thought not to be infectious until symptomatic, no\ntravel contacts are being followed up. Only 6 cases of Lassa fever have\nbeen imported into the UK since 1976.\nLassa fever background\n----------------------\nLassa fever is a zoonosis, an infection acquired from _Mastomys\nnatalensis_, the multimammate rat. It is endemic in west Africa. The risk\nof further transmission to humans of Lassa fever in the UK from imported\ncases is extremely low, and the natural reservoir is not found in the UK.\nRisk is confined to those who have had direct physical contact with body\nfluids from the patient during the infectious period. There have been no\nrecorded transmissions by such a route in the UK, including 74 health care\nworker contacts followed up by serology after the case in 2000 (2). There\nis no risk to the general public including travelling companions. A review\nof casual contacts that took place in the 1960/70s found no transmission\namong airline passengers travelling with confirmed Lassa cases (3).\nReferences:\n1. Advisory Committee on Dangerous Pathogens. Management and control of\nviral haemorrhagic fevers. London: The Stationery Office, 1996.\n2. CDSC. Lassa fever imported to England. Commun Dis Rep CDR Wkly 2000;\n10(11): 99.\n3. Galbraith NS, Berrie JRH, Forbes P, Young S. Public Health aspects of\nviral haemorrhagic fevers in Britain. The man, who recently flew to the country from West\nAfrica, is only the 7th person in the UK ever to suffer from Lassa fever\nvirus infection, which is classed as one of the world's most dangerous\ndiseases. It can cause violent seizures, and internal bleeding, leading to\ndeath.\nPublic health officials are now trying to track down people who came into\nclose contact with the patient, while refusing to release details of the\nflight which brought him to the United Kingdom. The patient walked into\nBarnet Hospital's Accident and Emergency Unit in north London complaining\nof malaria-like symptoms.\nHe was moved to the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead for monitoring then\ntransferred to their high-security isolation unit at nearby Coppetts Wood\nHospital. A spokeswoman for the infectious disease center said: 'We can\nconfirm that a patient, who has recently returned from West Africa, has\nLassa fever. The patient was treated appropriately at a high security\ninfectious diseases unit in North London and has now recovered. As a\nprecaution, healthcare workers and close contacts, such as household\nmembers, have been contacted and are being followed up, although the risk\nof them having acquired the infection is low.' The man has now been moved\nback to a medium secure unit at the Royal Free Hospital, as he is no longer\ncontagious.\nThe spokeswoman added that, since 1976, there have been only 6 other cases\nin Britain. The current victim is the 1st case in the UK since a soldier\nwas infected in Sierra Leone in 2003. At that time, around 90 people, who\ncame into contact with the soldier, were put under surveillance to prevent\nan outbreak.\nIn August [2004], a 38 year old American returning from a trip to Liberia\ndied in New Jersey. Preliminary\nlaboratory testing performed by the WHO Collaborating Centers, the National\nInstitute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa has confirmed Lassa fever\ninfection. A team from WHO headquarters and the WHO Country Office is\nassessing the situation and the need to conduct further investigations,\nassisting patient management in the isolation units of Kenema hospital, and\nidentifying measures to control the outbreak.\n--\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\n[Lassa fever is a hemorrhagic fever caused by Lassa virus, a\nnegative-strand RNA virus with a bipartite genome belonging to the family\n_Arenaviridae_, that is endemic in parts of West Africa. Lassa virus\nbelongs to the old world group of arenaviruses. Like all arenaviruses these\nviruses cause persistent infections of rodents (_Mastomys_ sp. in the case\nof Lassa virus) usually without obvious signs of disease. Humans and other\nanimals are infected through contact with rodent excreta, particularly\nurine. Cases of Lassa fever are limited to West Africa and have been\nreported most frequently from Sierra Leone, and to a lesser extent from\nNigeria, Liberia, and Guinea. In endemic areas of rural West Africa\nsubclinical infection is common, but occasional outbreaks with high\nmortality rates have been recorded. There is also risk of transmission of\ndisease when unrecognized Lassa fever cases are imported into non-endemic\nregions for treatment of haemorrhagic disease. Kenema district is located\nin the south of Sierra Leone close to the border with Liberia. Further\ninformation on this outbreak in Kenema is awaited.- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A team from WHO headquarters and the WHO Country Office is\nassessing the situation and the need to conduct further investigations,\nassisting patient management in the isolation units of Kenema hospital, and\nidentifying measures to control the outbreak.\n Preliminary\nlaboratory testing performed by the WHO Collaborating Centers, the National\nInstitute for Communicable Diseases, South Africa has confirmed Lassa fever\ninfection. --\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\n [Lassa fever is a hemorrhagic fever caused by Lassa virus, a\nnegative-strand RNA virus with a bipartite genome belonging to the family\n_Arenaviridae_, that is endemic in parts of West Africa. There is also risk of transmission of\ndisease when unrecognized Lassa fever cases are imported into non-endemic\nregions for treatment of haemorrhagic disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "lassa fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liberia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206659", "headline": "PRO/AH> Lassa fever, imported - USA (NJ) ex Liberia (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206659", "date": "2004-09-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER, IMPORTED - USA (NEW JERSEY) EX LIBERIA (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 30 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Review (MMWR) Fri 1 Oct 2004 /\n53(38);894-897 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5338a2.htm>\n\nImported Lassa Fever --- New Jersey, 2004\n-----------------------------------------\nLassa fever is an acute viral illness caused by Lassa virus, which is\nhosted by rodents in the _Mastomys natalensis_ species complex and rarely\nimported to countries outside of those areas in Africa where the disease is\nendemic (1). Lassa fever is characterized by fever, muscle aches, sore\nthroat, nausea, vomiting, and chest and abdominal pain. Approximately 15\npercent to 20 percent of patients hospitalized for Lassa fever die from the\nillness; however, approximately 80 percent of human infections with Lassa\nvirus are mild or asymptomatic, and 1 percent of infections overall result\nin death (1). On 28 Aug 2004, a man aged 38 years residing in New Jersey\ndied from Lassa fever after returning from travel to West Africa. This\nreport summarizes the clinical and epidemiologic investigations conducted\nby federal, state, and local public health agencies. The findings\nillustrate the need for clinicians and public health officials to remain\nalert to emerging infectious diseases and to !\ninstitute appropriate measures to promptly identify and limit spread of\nunusual pathogens.\nCase Report\n-----------\nThe patient, a businessman who was born in Liberia, had resided in the\nUnited States for 5 years. During the 4-month period preceding\nhospitalization, he had been in West Africa, commuting frequently between\nLiberia and Sierra Leone, where he owned farms. One day in August 2004, the\npatient began to experience fever, chills, severe sore throat, diarrhea,\nand back pain. 2 days later, he left Freetown, Sierra Leone, and traveled\nby airplane through London, England, arriving in Newark, New Jersey. He\nthen traveled from Newark to his home by train.\nWithin hours of his arrival in the United States, the patient sought\ntreatment and was hospitalized in Trenton, New Jersey, for persistent\nfever, chills, sore throat, diarrhea, and back pain. On admission, the\npatient was alert and had a temperature of 103.6 F (39.8 C). Differential\ndiagnoses at this time included malaria and typhoid fever. On the 3rd and\n4th days of hospitalization, despite treatment with antimalarial and\nantibiotic therapy, the patient's condition deteriorated, and adult\nrespiratory distress syndrome was diagnosed. He was subsequently intubated\nand mechanically ventilated. Yellow fever and Lassa fever were considered\nas possible diagnoses. The New Jersey Department of Health and Senior\nServices (NJDHSS) was notified, CDC was consulted, and arrangements to\nadminister intravenous ribavirin under an investigational new drug protocol\nwere initiated. However, 6 hours later, the patient died before the drug\ncould be administered.\nClinical and postmortem specimens were sent to CDC for specific diagnostic\ntesting. Lassa fever was confirmed by using serum antigen detection,\nimmunohistochemical staining of postmortem liver-biopsy specimens, virus\nisolation in cell culture, and sequencing of Lassa virus by reverse\ntranscriptase-polymerase chain reaction.\nInvestigation\n-------------\nAn investigation was conducted to identify persons who might have had\ndirect contact with the patient or his body fluids while he was ill.\nContacts were categorized into low- and high-risk categories on the basis\nof multiple criteria.\nA total of 188 persons had contact with the patient during the period when\nhe was likely infectious; of these, 5 persons were classified as at high\nrisk and 183 as at low risk. The 5 at high risk were the patient's wife, 3\nof their children, and the patient's brother, who was a hospital visitor;\neach reportedly had unprotected exposure to the patient's body fluids\nduring his illness. Contacts at low risk included 9 other family members,\n139 health-care workers employed at the Trenton hospital (including 42\nlaboratory workers, 32 nurses, and 11 physicians), and 16 laboratory\nworkers employed at commercial laboratories in Virginia and California. In\naddition, 19 contacts at low risk were exposed as passengers on the flight\nfrom London to Newark.\nThe NJDHSS notified CDC's Division of Global Migration and Quarantine\n(DGMQ) of possible travel-related exposures. Because the patient reported\nillness onset 3 days before air travel, DGMQ searched for those airline\npassengers who had been seated within 6 feet of the patient. Passengers\nwere traced by using information from travel reservation records and\ncustoms declaration forms. 19 passengers seated near the patient were\nidentified. Within 5 days of notification, 13 of the 19 passengers had been\ninterviewed; within 8 days, 3 more had been contacted. The remaining 3\ncould not be contacted. 17 of 19 passengers were citizens of the United\nKingdom, and authorities in that country were notified; 2 of the passengers\nwere U.S. citizens. Interviewed passengers did not report contact with the\npatient's body fluids and were considered to have low-risk exposure. All\npassengers contacted were healthy; none reported fever as of 14 Sep 2004,\nwhich marked the end of the 21-day incubation period for Lassa fever for\nthis group.\nAll contacts at high risk (i.e., 5 family members) were monitored for\ntemperature of >101 F (>38.3 C) twice daily for 21 days after their last\npotential exposure to the patient on 28 Aug 2004. A public health nurse\nvisited the family contacts each morning and recorded their temperatures.\nIn the afternoon, the contacts recorded their own temperatures and reported\nthe results.\nThe majority of contacts at low risk (i.e., 9 other family members and 139\nhealth-care workers) were instructed to record their own temperatures at\nleast twice daily and report the results. Other contacts at low risk (i.e.,\nthe 16 laboratory workers and 19 air passengers) were asked to self-monitor\nfor temperature of >101 F (>38.3 C) and other symptoms compatible with\nLassa fever.\nNo restriction was placed on work or movement for asymptomatic adults at\neither high or low risk. However, to facilitate monitoring, the patient's\nchildren were restricted from participating in school activities. None of\nthe contacts at high risk reported any illness compatible with Lassa fever\nas of 18 Sep 2004, which ended their 21-day incubation period.\n(Reported by: P Aufiero, MD, N Karabulut, MD, D Rumowitz, S Shah, DO,\nCapital Health System, Trenton; J Nsubuga, MPH, B Piepszak, RD Salter, MA,\nCity of Trenton Div of Health; E Bresnitz, MD, CR Lacy, MD, C Robertson,\nMD, C Tan, MD, New Jersey Dept of Health and Senior Svcs. Div of Global\nMigration and Quarantine, Div of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases, National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases; ET Tan, MBBS, EIS Officer, CDC.)\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n--------------------\nThis report describes the 1st case of imported Lassa fever diagnosed in the\nUnited States since 1989 (2). In West Africa, Lassa fever is endemic,\ncausing 100 000 to 300 000 human infections and approximately 5000 deaths\neach year (1).\nOther than in regions where it is endemic, Lassa fever is encountered\nrarely. Cases identified in areas where Lassa fever is not endemic usually\nare imported, often by persons returning from West Africa (2). To date,\napproximately 20 cases of imported Lassa fever have been reported\nworldwide. The risk for human-to-human transmission of Lassa fever is low\n(3,4); however, healthcare-associated transmission has occurred in areas\nwhere Lassa fever is endemic, and one instance of asymptomatic\nseroconversion was reported in a European physician (4). Meticulous\nadherence to appropriate infection-control practices to prevent unprotected\nexposure to blood or other body fluids is essential to the safe management\nof patients with possible Lassa fever and to the protection of health-care\nworkers (2). Family members and others visiting a hospitalized patient must\nbe instructed to adhere to infection-control precautions and avoid exposure\nto potentially infectious blood or body fluids.\nIn the absence of proven effectiveness, oral ribavirin prophylaxis was not\nrecommended for persons who might have been exposed to the patient\ndescribed in this report. Instead, a standard treatment regimen of\nintravenous ribavirin was recommended for any contacts with clinical\nevidence of infection during the incubation period. However, none of the\ncontacts had illness compatible with Lassa fever.\nIncreasing international travel has resulted in importation of microbial\nagents not endemic to the United States, posing diagnostic challenges to\nhealth-care providers. In addition to routine evaluation, clinicians should\nconsider both uncommon and common causes of fever (e.g., malaria) in\npersons arriving from Africa. Clinical histories should include careful\nassessment of travel to regions where uncommon diseases are endemic (e.g.,\nfor Lassa fever, Liberia, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone). Every effort should\nbe made to expedite delivery of clinical specimens to appropriate\ndiagnostic laboratories.\nThe nonspecific presentation of Lassa fever and related viral infections\nthat can cause viral hemorrhagic fever syndromes underscores the need for\nconsistent application of infection-control practices. Suspected cases of\nLassa fever or related infections should be reported immediately to\nhospital infection-control professionals and to state and local health\ndepartments for treatment recommendations and to facilitate implementation\nof infection-control precautions and tracing of contacts. Clinicians also\nshould consult CDC's Special Pathogens Branch (telephone 404-639-1115),\nwhere specialized containment facilities exist to allow diagnostic\nconfirmation by serologic, virologic, molecular, and pathology techniques.\nState health departments should notify DGMQ immediately of travel-related\nimportations of suspected communicable diseases to ensure that prompt risk\nassessments, notifications, and appropriate containment measures are\nimplemented for exposed travelers.\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Lassa fever fact sheet. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and\nHuman Services, CDC; 2004. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/lassaf.htm>.\n2. 8 people have died of highly infectious Lassa fever in central\nSierra Leone and the disease has spread to camps for Liberian refugees in\nthe region, health officials said on Wednesday.\nSome 80 patients were receiving treatment at the Kenema Government\nHospital, 200km east of Freetown, the manager of the disease prevention\nprogramme in the ministry of health, Magnus Gborie said.\nThe disease, which leads to high fever, aches, skin trouble and potential\ndeath through heart or kidney failure, is spread by bush rats which urinate\non food, health officials said.\nPeople who eat the contaminated food become infected within 24 hours. Lassa\nfever is endemic in both the Kenema and Kailahun districts of Sierra Leone,\nbut has previously been kept in check with medical assistance from the\nCentre for Disease Control in Atlanta in the United States.\nHowever, such aid was scaled down during the civil war that wracked the\nwest African country from 1991 to 2001.\nGborie said officials from the health ministry, the UN World Health\nOrganisation and a number of non-governmental organisations have set up a\ntask force to combat the outbreak.\n4 UN peacekeepers in a force deployed in the country have been treated for\nLassa fever and discharged from hospital, officials said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Lassa fever virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_, a group of\nnegative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses with bisegmented genomes.\nArenaviruses occur throughout the world, their distribution being\ndetermined by their natural reservoir hosts, primarily rodents.\nArenaviruses are associated with only 2 of the 30 families of rodents; the\n_Muridae_ (house mice and rats) and the _Cricetidae_ (voles, deer mice, and\ngerbils). They are maintained within their rodent hosts in a chronic\ncarrier state; in the case of Lassa fever virus, long-term viremia and\nlittle signs of disease. Most arenavirus species occur in the New World and\na few (_Guarito virus_, _Junin virus_, _Machupo virus_, and _Sabia virus_)\nare associated with severe hemorrhagic fevers in humans. 5 arenavirus\nspecies are present in the Old World, only 2 of which are associated with\nhuman disease: _Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus_ (LCMV) and _Lassa fever\nvirus_. LCMV occurs worldwide and causes mild to severe disease, whereas\nLassa fever virus occurs only in West Africa (Sierra Leone and Nigeria) and\nis associated with severe, often fatal infection of humans. The rodent\nreservoir of Lassa fever virus is _Mastomys natalensis_, an animal which\ninhabits human dwellings and surroundings. Rodent-to-human is the\npredominant route of transmission of infection in human victims and\nprobably occurs via aerosols or contact with rodent fluids and detritus.\nLess frequently human-to-human transmission can occur also in natural and\nhospital settings, probably because of the high aerosol stability of the\nvirus; hence the need for high-security containment in hospital\nenvironments. - Mod.CP\n[In the prior ProMED-mail posting on this outbreak (see Lassa fever -\nSierra Leone (south & east) 20030404.0827 ) we did not have information on\nthe numbers of cases involved. This newswire suggests that this current\noutbreak is significant with at least 80 cases and 8 deaths reported thusfar.\nAccording to the Global Infectious Diseases & Epidemiology Network (GIDEON)\n<http://www.gideononline.com> Lassa fever is most common in the eastern\nregion of Sierra Leone - where one to 4 Mastomys are found in every\nhousehold in this area, of which 1--20 percent are infected with the\nvirus. In some areas of eastern Sierra Leone, the disease accounts for 30\npercent of medical death in-hospital, 30 percent of deafness and 70 percent\nof spontaneous abortion. 8--52 of the population are seropositive. An\noutbreak was reported in Kenema District in 1995, encompassing 167 cases\n(60 fatal) - most patients were adolescent females. 799 cases (148 fatal)\nwere reported in 1996, including 99 cases (13 fatal) from Kenema District\nduring November and December. 353 (43 fatal) cases were reported during\nJanuary to April 1997.\nThere is a very informative fact sheet on Lassa fever at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/lassaf.htm> 'There are\na number of ways in which the virus may be transmitted, or spread, to\nhumans. The Mastomys rodents shed the virus in urine and droppings.\nTherefore, the virus can be transmitted through direct contact with these\nmaterials, through touching objects or eating food contaminated with these\nmaterials, or through cuts or sores. Because Mastomys rodents often live in\nand around homes and scavenge on human food remains or poorly stored food,\ntransmission of this sort is common. Contact with the virus also may occur\nwhen a person inhales tiny particles in the air contaminated with rodent\nexcretions. This is called aerosol or airborne transmission. Finally,\nbecause Mastomys rodents are sometimes consumed as a food source, infection\nmay occur via direct contact when they are caught and prepared for food.' -\nMod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Apr 2003\n According to the Global Infectious Diseases & Epidemiology Network (GIDEON)\n<http://www.gideononline.com> Lassa fever is most common in the eastern\nregion of Sierra Leone - where one to 4 Mastomys are found in every\nhousehold in this area, of which 1--20 percent are infected with the\nvirus. The man, who became\nill on Thu 30 Jan 2003, is being cared for at a high-security\ninfectious diseases unit in London and is in a stable condition.\nSince 1970, there have been at least 16 cases of Lassa fever imported\ninto Europe or North America; in none of these has onward\ntransmission to another person been reported.\nFrom cases of person-to-person spread that have occurred in\ndeveloping countries, it is clear that people are only infectious\nwhile symptoms are present or in the period of convalescence, and\nthen only through direct contact with bodily fluids. No such\ntransmission has occurred in the United Kingdom (UK). However, in\naccordance with established guidelines in the UK, the patient is\nbeing treated in a high-security infectious diseases unit. As a\nprecaution, close contacts of the patient including hospital staff\ninvolved in the patient's care, and particularly those who have had\ncontact with the patient's bodily fluids, will be monitored by\noccupational health staff and given advice about their level of risk,\nwhich is low.\nThis follows a previous case in a British aid worker in Sierra Leone\n(1), a case imported from Sierra Leone to the Netherlands (2), and 2\ncases imported to Germany from Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire, all in 2000\n(3).\nPrepared by the Editorial team (<eurowkly@phls.org.uk>),\nEurosurveillance editorial office.\nReferences:\n1. UK ex Sierra Leone", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203335", "date": "2003-02-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER, IMPORTED - UK EX SIERRA LEONE\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 10 Feb 2003\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO, Disease Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_02_10a/en/>\n\nImported case of Lassa fever in United Kingdom\n----------------------------------------------\nThe diagnosis of Lassa fever in a British soldier recently returned\nfrom duty in rural Sierra Leone has been confirmed by virological\ntests performed at the Enteric, Respiratory and Neurological Virus\nLaboratory at the Central Public Health Laboratory, London, United\nKingdom. He had been based in an area endemic for Lassa fever. He is\ncurrently being treated at the high-security infectious diseases unit\nat Coppetts Wood Hospital, London. This is the sixth case of Lassa\nfever to have been imported to the United Kingdom since 1976.\nFor more information about Lassa fever see the WHO fact sheet\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact179.html>\n--\nMarianne Hopp\n<mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 10 Feb 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly, Mon 10 Feb 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030206.asp>\n\nLassa fever in a UK soldier recently returned from Sierra Leone\n--------------------------------------------------\nA case of Lassa fever has been confirmed in a British soldier\nreturned from Sierra Leone, West Africa, it is reported in 3 press\nreleases issued today by the Public Health Laboratory Service in\nLondon, the Royal Free Hampstead Hospital in London, and the\nBirmingham Heartlands Hospital, and Birmingham Public Health\nOfficials. The man, who became ill on Thu 30 Jan 2003, is being cared\nfor at a high-security infectious diseases unit in London and is in a\nstable condition.\nSince 1970, there have been at least 16 cases of Lassa fever imported\ninto Europe or North America; in none of these has onward\ntransmission to another person been reported.\nFrom cases of person-to-person spread that have occurred in\ndeveloping countries, it is clear that people are only infectious\nwhile symptoms are present or in the period of convalescence, and\nthen only through direct contact with bodily fluids. No such\ntransmission has occurred in the United Kingdom (UK). However, in\naccordance with established guidelines in the UK, the patient is\nbeing treated in a high-security infectious diseases unit. As a\nprecaution, close contacts of the patient including hospital staff\ninvolved in the patient's care, and particularly those who have had\ncontact with the patient's bodily fluids, will be monitored by\noccupational health staff and given advice about their level of risk,\nwhich is low.\nThis follows a previous case in a British aid worker in Sierra Leone\n(1), a case imported from Sierra Leone to the Netherlands (2), and 2\ncases imported to Germany from Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire, all in 2000\n(3).\nPrepared by the Editorial team (<eurowkly@phls.org.uk>),\nEurosurveillance editorial office.\nReferences:\n1. Jones J. Lassa fever imported to England. Eurosurveillance Weekly\n2000; 4: 000311\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2000/000316.asp>)\n2. Eurosurveillance. Imported case of Lassa fever in the Netherlands.\nEurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4:000721\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2000/000727.asp>)\n3. Lieftucht A, Kiehl W. Lassa fever in a German student returning\nfrom Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire. Eurosurveillance Weekly 2000; 4: 000119\n(<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2000/000119.asp>)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Lassa fever virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_, a group\nof negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses with bisegmented\ngenomes. Arenaviruses occur throughout the world, their distribution\nbeing determined by their natural reservoir hosts, primarily rodents.\nArenaviruses are associated with only 2 of the 30 families of\nrodents; the _Muridae_ (house mice and rats) and the _Cricetidae_\n(voles, deer mice, and gerbils). They are maintained within their\nrodent hosts in a chronic carrier state; in the case of Lassa fever\nvirus, long-term viremia and little signs of disease. Most arenavirus\nspecies occur in the New World and a few (_Guarito virus_, _Junin\nvirus_, _Machupo virus_, and _Sabia virus_) are associated with\nsevere hemorrhagic fevers in humans. 5 arenavirus species are present\nin the Old World, only 2 of which are associated with human disease:\n_Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus_ (LCMV) and _Lassa fever virus_.\nLCMV occurs worldwide and causes mild to severe disease, whereas\nLassa fever virus occurs only in West Africa (Sierra Leone and\nNigeria) and is associated with severe, often fatal infection of\nhumans. The rodent reservoir of Lassa fever virus is _Mastomys\nnatalensis_, an animal which inhabits human dwellings and\nsurroundings. Rodent-to-human is the predominant route of\ntransmission of infection in human victims and probably occurs via\naerosols or contact with rodent fluids and detritus. Less frequently\nhuman-to-human transmission can occur also in natural and hospital\nsettings, probably because of the high aerosol stability of the\nvirus; hence the need for high-security containment in hospital\nenvironments. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A case of Lassa fever has been confirmed in a British soldier\nreturned from Sierra Leone, West Africa, it is reported in 3 press\nreleases issued today by the Public Health Laboratory Service in\nLondon, the Royal Free Hampstead Hospital in London, and the\nBirmingham Heartlands Hospital, and Birmingham Public Health\nOfficials. As a\nprecaution, close contacts of the patient including hospital staff\ninvolved in the patient's care, and particularly those who have had\ncontact with the patient's bodily fluids, will be monitored by\noccupational health staff and given advice about their level of risk,\nwhich is low. SIERRA LEONE\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nDate: Mon 13 Mar 2000\nFrom: Marjorie P. Pollack <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: WHO/CSR, 13 March 2000\n<http://www.who.int/emc/outbreak_news/n2000/march/13mar2000.html>\n\nA suspected, imported case of Lassa fever has been reported from the United\nKingdom. A 50-year-old British national working in Daru, Sierra Leone\nbecame ill with fever on 21 February and was airlifted to Freetown. He\nremained unwell, and on 5 March was evacuated to the UK by air ambulance.\nHe was admitted to the Hospital for Tropical Diseases, London, and then\ntransferred to Coppetts Wood Hospital, where he is being managed in high\nsecurity isolation facilities.\nLassa fever is suspected on the basis of clinical findings and preliminary\ntest results. Tests for other known viral haemorrhagic fevers have so far\nproved negative. Confirmatory tests for Lassa fever are in progress at the\nEnteric and Respiratory Virus Laboratory, Central Public Health Laboratory,\nLondon, and the results are expected within 24 hours. More than 90\npotential contacts of this patient have been identified, both in Sierra\nLeone and the UK. All have been contacted and are being monitored.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@promedmail.org\n[(1) Another report, this one via George Robertson and Martha Cosgriff,\nindicated the patient had been working for the Department for International\nDevelopment in a remote rural area, helping former soldiers return to\ncivilian life after the country's civil war. Apparently, the patient is\nbeing treated with an anti-viral drug. Attending physicians said he had\nimproved at first but on Sunday his lungs began to fail and he was placed\non a ventilator.\nThe report also said, among other things: Lassa fever is a viral\nhaemorrhagic fever is spread by rats but can also be transmitted by direct\ncontact with bodily fluids. There have been 12 cases of Lassa fever\nimported to Europe and North America since 1970, with none resulting in\nfurther infection of other medical staff or patients. The disease carries a\ndeath rate of 15-20% among those taken to hospital. William Weir, a\nconsultant in infectious and tropical disease, who is treating the man,\nsaid: 'He is critically ill. I spoke to his wife yesterday and she is\nunderstandably upset. In situations like this we have to be completely\ntruthful with relatives and tell them exactly what the patient's future\ncontains.'\nThe hospital said there was no danger of the virus spreading to the public\nbut doctors, nurses, porters and ambulance staff were being interviewed\nabout their contact with the patient and some would be kept under\nsurveillance for signs of the disease so treatment could be started\nimmediately if they became ill.\nA spokeswoman for the Royal Free NHS Trust, which runs Coppetts Wood, said:\n'His status [as a carrier of an infectious tropical disease] was not clear\nwhen he came in.' Patients at the Hospital for Tropical Diseases were in\n'minimal' danger of being infected, she said, because the patient had been\nkept in an isolation room. 'This unit regularly deals with very sick\npatients, and so the hygiene and infection control regimens are very\nstrict. The likelihood of anyone at the hospital being exposed to the\ninfection is minimal.'\nLassa fever's incubation period is between three and 21 days and typical\nsymptoms are soaring temperature (up to 41C or 106F) headache, lethargy and\nmuscular pains. There is also often a rash caused by bleeding into the skin\nand mucous membranes. In the latest case, the man developed a nose bleed\nwhich, with the results of blood tests, caused doctors to suspect Lassa fever.\n(2)\nThe diagnosis of Lassa fever has now been confirmed:\n<http://www.who.int/emc/outbreak_news/n2000/march/14mar2000.html> WHO CSR\nThe patient 's condition is reported to have improved slightly, but he\nremains seriously ill. Monitoring of close contacts is continuing, and will\nbe carried out through the potential incubation period of the illness.\n(3) Dan Shapiro and I had the same thought, that a single case of Lassa\nfever, in a resident of a major industrialized country receives more media\nhype than many cases of Marburg in developing countries. - Mod. Only 12 hours later\nwe had a positive RT-PCR [reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain\nreaction test] result for Lassa virus RNA. This result was reported to the\nclinicians at Wuerzburg on Wednesday (12 Jan 2000) early in the\nmorning (7:30 a.m.).\nAlso ribavirin treatment was initiated.\nIn the meantime the amplified material was sequenced (82% homology\nto Josiah, 65% to Nigeria strain). The virus is growing in tissue culture.\nThe patient had become sick in Ivory Coast on 2 Jan 2000 and returned\nsick to Frankfurt Airport on 7 Jan 2000. She only arrived in the hospital\nfor tropical diseases at Wuerzburg 3 day later. Thus the specific\ntreatment started very late. Prof. Fleischer (Wuerzburg) told me this\nmorning that in addition to pneumonia and hepatitis, also renal failure\nand CNS symptoms were seen.\n--\nHerbert Schmitz MD\nDep.Virology, Bernhard-Nocht Institute\nBernhard-Nocht Str.74\nD-20359 Hamburg, Germany\nSchmitz@bni.uni-hamburg.de\n[Dr Schmitz omitted to refer to his published work on Lassa diagnosis:\nLunkenheimer K, Hufert FT, Schmitz H\nDetection of Lassa virus RNA in specimens from patients with Lassa\nfever by using the polymerase chain reaction. Virology. 1989\nFeb;168(2):421-5.]\nThe Josiah strain is from Sierra Leone. The virus was previously\nknown from that country, Liberia, Guinea & Nigeria.
