TP\n3149\n7 Jan 2000 Lisbon - Frankfurt/M. Air Portugal flight no. TP 5576.\nThe Ministry for Social Affairs in Baden-Wuerttemberg issued the\nfollowing information on 12 January 2000 asking the media to\ndisseminate it nationally: 'All passengers are urgently requested to\ncontact tomorrow (i.e. 13 Jan 2000) their local health departments.\nPassengers with the following symptoms are asked to go to hospital\nimmediately: fever greater than 38.5 degrees C, headache, sore throat,\ncoughing and intestinal upset.\nThe following details are requested from passengers:\nName\nSeat number\nContact address and telephone no.\n*******************************\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 13 Jan 2000 10:33:01 +0100\nFrom: leitritz@m3401.mpk.med.uni-muenchen.de\nVia: Wolfgang Preiser <W.Preiser@em.uni-frankfurt.de>\nSource: Press release of the Robert Koch-Institut, Berlin\n(Translation by W. Preiser)\n\n13.01.2000\nDiagnosis of Lassa fever confirmed\nA 23-year old female student who had been transferred from a hospital\nin Schwaedbisch-Hall to the renowned Mission Hospital in Wuerzburg\non Tuesday, 11 Jan 2000, due to continuing high fever has been\nconfirmed as suffering from Lassa fever. The young woman who is\nstudying in Duesseldorf had returned to Germany at the beginning of\nthe year from a seven-week African holiday in Cote d'Ivoire (Ivory\nCoast) and Ghana.\nLassa fever is caused by a virus which is transmitted to humans from a\nsmall rat widely occurring in African dwellings -- mostly through food\ncontaminated with rodent excrement. Human-to-human transmission is\npossible under bad hygienic conditions through direct contact with\nblood, saliva, vomitus or urine from diseased individuals, particularly\nduring nursing. Most infected individuals start being infectious only\nwhen they reach the acute febrile phase. The disease, a so-called viral\nhemorrhagic fever, can lead to a severe bleeding disorder with shock\nand circulatory collapse. In hospitalised patients mortality is about 15 %.\nOften the disease may run a mild or asymptomatic course. There is\ncurrently no vaccine.\nAfter other diseases had been excluded and the suspicion of Lassa fever\ncorroborated, the necessary measures were co-ordinated in close\ncollaboration between the Medical Director of the Mission Hospital in\nWuerzburg, Professor Dr. Fleischer, the responsible outbreak\nadministrator of the Health Ministries of Bavaria and\nBaden-Wuerttemberg, the Robert Koch-Institut (http://www.rki.de)\nand the Bernhard Nocht-Institut in Hamburg\n(http://www.bni.uni-hamburg.de) where the necessary laboratory\ninvestigations are done. The Federal Health Ministry, the European\nUnion and the WHO were informed through the notification channels in\nplace for these cases.\nThe patient is being treated in an isolated part of the Hospital. She is\nin a serious state. Isolation ensures that there is no risk for other\npatients nor for the general population. Family members and friends\nwho had been in immediate contact, and the medical personnel who\nlooked after the patient in Schwaebisch Hall, are being interviewed by\nthe health authorities regarding details of their contacts and informed\nabout possible symptoms. Contact persons are being asked to take their\ntemperature twice daily, to be vigilant re possible symptoms and to\ncontact the Hospital in Schwaebisch Hall in case of symptoms. As it is a\nrare but severe infectious disease the health authorities are doing\neverything to prevent infection of others.\n--\nPress release:\nDate: Wed, 12 Jan 2000 19:19:17 +0100\nFrom: 'Muschketat, Edgar' <MuschketatE@RKI.DE>\nEdgar Muschketat\nRobert Koch-Institut\nPressesprecher\nTel: 01888.754 2286\nFax: 01888.754 2601\nE-Mail: MuschketatE@rki.de\n***\n[2]\nDate: Thu, 13 Jan 2000 11:40:19 +0100\nFrom: leitritz@m3401.mpk.med.uni-muenchen.de\nVia: Wolfgang Preiser <W.Preiser@em.uni-frankfurt.de>\nSource: Pressemitteilungen (press release) des Robert Koch-Instituts\n<RKI_PRESSEDIENST@LISTSERV.GMD.DE>\n\nFurther update - RKI press release - imported Lassa fever - Germany\nWed, 12 Jan 2000 19:19:17 +0100\nSuspicion of Lassa fever confirmed (Update)\nThe 23-year old female German student who is currently being treated\nfor Lassa fever in the Mission Hospital in Wuerzburg arrived in\nGermany, according to latest information, not on New Year's eve but on\n7 Jan 2000, probably through Frankfurt Rhein-Main airport.\nAccording to further information she spent the night of 6-7 Jan 2000 in\na still unknown hotel in Lisbon, Portugal [now doubtful -- see [3]\nbelow - Mod.JW], and had already fallen ill with high fever in Cote\nd'Ivoire (Ivory Coast) on 2 January 2000. She had not taken malaria\nprophylaxis. Two yellow fever vaccinations had apparently been done\nin time before the trip.\nIt is still unclear whether the patient had returned from Abidjan (Ivory\nCoast) or Ouagadougou (Burkina Faso) to Europe. As she had\napparently fallen ill before her departure from Africa, a potential risk to\nfellow travellers on the plane cannot be excluded with certainty. At\npresent the flights she used from Ouagadougou or Abidjan and from\nLisbon are being traced [these are reported below - Mod.JW].\n--\nEdgar Muschketat\nRobert Koch-Institu\nPressesprecher\nTel: 01888.754 2286\nFax: 01888.754 2601\nE-Mail: MuschketatE@rki.de\n*****\n[3]\nDate: Thu, 13 Jan 2000 13:28:37 +0100\nFrom: Wolfgang Preiser <W.Preiser@em.uni-frankfurt.de>\nSource: Update information from the Robert Koch-Institute\n13 January 1 p.m. local time (GMT+1)\n(Translation W. Preiser)\nLassa fever import 7 January 2000\nThe 23-year old German student who was transferred from a hospital in\nSchwaebisch Hall to the renowned Mission Hospital in Wuerzburg on\nMonday, 10 January 2000, due to continuing high fever has been\nconfirmed with Lassa fever. The number of cases increased from 45\nwith 7 deaths (15.6%) in January to 75 cases and 9 deaths (12.0%) in\nFebruary, and 147 cases with 20 deaths (13.4%) in March but decreased to 86\ncases with 7 deaths (8.1%) in April. The resumption of civil unrest in\nKenema in late April and the brief closure of the Kenema hospital may have\nadversely affected reporting. During 1996, a total of 470 cases with 110\ndeaths (23.4%) were reported. While the majority of cases sought medical\ncare in Kenema four cases were identified in Freetown. Initially, cases\nseeking medical care in Freetown were transported to Kenema but an isolation\nward is now being established in Freetown using health staff trained at the\nLassa fever isolation ward in Kenema to ensure prompt management of suspect\ncases.\nThe Ministry of Health and Sanitation together with WHO and MERLIN is\nplanning activities to prevent the spread of the disease and improve\nmanagement of suspect cases. Key district health personnel will be included\nin a nation-wide training programme on Lassa fever control that is planned\nfor later in the year. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is studying a\nplan for rodent control. Treatment with ribavirin was resumed in mid-April\nwith the arrival of new supplies of the drug after the stock was depleted in\nFebruary. Ribavirin will be distributed to other areas where health\npersonnel are familiar with administration of this drug for the treatment of\nLassa fever. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation is also establishing a\nnational Lassa fever control programme with a programme manager based in\nKenema.\n_________________________________\nNOTES CONCERNING THIS SERVICE:\nThe Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) serves as an\nessential instrument for the rapid and accurate\ndissemination of epidemiological information on cases and\noutbreaks of diseases under the International Health\nRegulations, other communicable diseases of public health\nimportance, including the newly emerging or re-emerging\ninfections, non-communicable diseases and other health\nproblems. Between November 1996 and 11 March 1997 a total of 239 cases\nwere admitted to hospital in Kenema District and 39 (16%) died. Of these\ncases, 140 with 23 deaths had occurred since 1 January 1997. A WHO mission\ninvestigated the situation in Kenema District from 14 to 21 February to\nredirect control activities, review existing surveillance activities identify\nfuture needs and prepare a plan of action. The cooperation of NGOs based in\nthe area such as MERLIN, UK, have resulted in improved communications for a\nrapid patient referral. A demonstration of barrier\nnursing techniqueswas also given.\n\nThe conclusion of the WHO support mission is that a major epidemic\nof Lassa Fever has occurred in Kailahun and Kenema Districts and is\ncontinuing as unusually large numbers of severely ill patients are\nstill being admitted to hospital, with a large number of deaths\nstill occurring.\n\nA total of 167 cases and 60 deaths have been recorded during the\nperiod January to 28 May 1996.\n\n........................................................................MHJ\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The conclusion of the WHO support mission is that a major epidemic\nof Lassa Fever has occurred in Kailahun and Kenema Districts and is\ncontinuing as unusually large numbers of severely ill patients are\nstill being admitted to hospital, with a large number of deaths\nstill occurring. Over 40 health personnel from the two districts affected attended a\nworkshop organized by the team which reviewed:- basic\nepidemiological concepts, the need for surveillance and the\nepidemiology and control of Lassa Fever. Date: Fri, 14 Jun 96 10:50:36 CET\nSubject: Communicable disease news - 14 June 1996\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: LASSA FEVER, UPDATE - SIERRA LEONE\n==================================\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["lassa fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-06-14 00:00:00", "1996-05-28 00:00:00", "2021-06-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kailahun", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188766", "headline": "PROMED: Lassa fever, update - Sierra Leone (2)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188766", "date": "1996-06-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "LASSA FEVER, UPDATE - SIERRA LEONE (2)\n======================================\nUpdate from MERLIN, a British medical agency in Sierra Leone.\nMedical Co-ordinator Dr. Rob Bennett has filed the following information from\nFreetown, Sierra Leone:\n'This looks like the most severe epidemic of Lassa fever in this region to\ndate. In May the number of cases jumped from 3 or 4 cases a week to 15 or 20.\nEfforts to contain the epidemic have been hampered by the war, which\ndestroyed medical services. Despite the current ceasefire, there is still\nlooting in the villages which hampers our ability to find and treat patients.\nThere is a lot we do not yet know about Lassa fever. Treatment is with\nRibavirin, an anti-viral drug, but it is only at the trial stage, and the\nmain clinical trials near Kenema were stopped by the war.'\nBackground\nOut of 167 patients identified in Kenema district since January 1996, 65 have\ndied. No one knows how many more are suffering in the interior of Sierra\nLeone, where populations have been cut off by guerrilla warfare.\nThe epidemic centres on Kenema, a district packed with thousands of people\nwho have fled from the recent civil war in Sierra Leone. Conditions in\nKenema are ideal for the spread of Lassa fever - unclean water, unhygienic\nfood storage, overcrowding and multiplying populations of rats. The virus is\nspread in rats' urine and excreta when they contaminate human food and water\nsupplies. The current outbreak follows an increase in the number of rats\nlocally.\nThe international medical team assisting Sierra Leone health officials\ncomprises: MERLIN (Medical Emergency Relief International), World Health\nOrganisation and the US Centers for Disease Control.\nMedical staff from MERLIN have helped local health officials to set up an\nisolation unit in Kenema Hospital for Lassa fever patients, with adequate\nbeds, water and sanitation. Supplies of Ribavirin, an antiviral drug, have\nbeen donated by CDC. MERLIN is assisting the hospital in sourcing other\nmedical supplies for the unit, including antibiotics, oral rehydration salts\nand intravenous liquids.\nMeanwhile, medical teams are visiting outlying villages around Kenema to\neducate villagers about the dangers of Lassa fever and how to avoid them\nthrough hygienic food and water storage, and control of rats.\nThe Sierra Leone government is co-ordinating with foreign agencies to provide\nhealth care and other basic services for displaced people across the country.\nIt has developed considerable experience with Lassa fever, which is endemic\nat a lower level throughout West Africa.\nLassa fever kills from shock and haemorrhaging of the internal organs,\nespecially the brain, kidneys and throat. Its early symptoms are easily\nmistaken for influenza. It can kill an adult within 10 days. It is one of a\ngroup of haemorraghic fevers which includes ebola, dengue and yellow fever,\nsome of Africa's most feared diseases.\n--\nMedical Emergency Relief International <Merlin@gn.apc.org>\n...............................................................chc\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Many\nthanks to those whos sent us this story. -- Mod CHC]\nDate: Thu, 24 Apr 1997 08:18:46 -0700\n>From news media sources\nThe worst-ever outbreak of Lassa fever, a deadly hemorrhagic disease, is\nthreatening to spread to Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown. Britain's Medical\nEmergency Relief International (MERLIN) said the case numbers had doubled\nsince December. Refugees fleeing the 6-year old civil war were packing into\nthe town of Kenema, 60 miles from the capital, and conditions are appropriate\nfor the spread of the highly virulent disease. 'This is the worst outbreak\nof Lassa fever since records began,' said Richard Allen, medical adviser to\nMERLIN. 'Now we are concerned that Lassa fever may spread from the bush to\nthe capital city, Freetown. The first suspected case of Lassa fever was\nadmitted to a Freetown hospital this week.'\nSpokesman Jonathan Lorie said there had been 239 cases with 35 deaths so far\nthis year -- compared to 367 cases and 93 deaths for the whole of last year.\n[>700 expected cases and >100 deaths in 1997 if the epidemic is not quenched.-\n- Mod CHC]. Cases occur each year. 'There was an epidemic last summer but it\ndied down in the autumn and the epidemic has renewed itself since January.\nHe also said that his group is buying as much ribaviran as it can.\n---\nDorothy B. Simms <TES@A1.cdrh.fda.gov>\nFound the following while reading an internet healthcare news listing.\n\n<http://www.fyionline.com/infoMCI/newsletter/HEALTH-MCI.html>\n\nLassa fever has killed nine people in eastern Sierra Leone. Physicians say\nthe outbreak is the worst on record there. Dr. Simon Mardel of the British\naid agency Medical Emergency Relief International (MERLIN) told Reuters by\ntelephone from Kenema that 74 sufferers had been admitted to hospital there\nin February -- the highest number on record.\n'This is clearly the worst (Lassa) epidemic -- and I mean epidemic in the\nreal sense -- in Sierra Leone to date. There has definitely been a rapid\ndeterioration recently,' Mardel said.\nThe Lassa fever ward opened May, 1996 but there were 10 cases in February\n199[7] and the annual average is usually around 35.\nLassa fever, spread by rat urine and feces or between humans, causes fever,\nminor hemorrhaging, vomiting, chest pains and low blood pressure. It killed\nabout one in four people infected in 1996.\nThe disease is endemic in eastern Sierra Leone but Mardel blamed the surge on\npoverty caused by almost five years of civil war and a rise in the rat\npopulation.\n'People don't have the mechanisms to destroy the rats or protect their food.\nThe human element of transmission has also increased because of overcrowding\nand, as a result of the war, there is less access to health care,' he said.\nThe only known cure, Ribavirin, a costly drug previously donated by the\nUnited States is no longer produced there. 'We have only one week's supply\nleft,' Mardel said. 'We are now looking for another source, maybe China or\nRussia.'\n---\nThomas Simms\nBiologist, Microbiology Branch\nDCLD, ODE, CDRH, FDA, HHS\nTEL: (301) 594-2096\nFAX: (301) 594-5941\ne-mail: <tes@fdadr.cdrh.fda.gov>\n...........................................................................chc\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Peters <cjp0@CIDDVD1.EM.CDC.GOV>\nAs the recent [today] ProMED-mail posting indicates, there has been an\nupsurge of Lassa fever patients arriving in the Kenema General Hopital in\nSierra Leone. This is presumably related to conditions attendant to the\ncivil unrest, but there are no objective data to identify the actual cause\n[of the increase in the number of cases], which is in part related to the\nrenewed ability to travel and seek therapy. We have been working with the\nGovernment of Sierra Leone, Medical Emergency Relief International, and the\nWHO to assess and respond to the problem. We have provided stocks of\nintravenous ribavirin (which will soon be depleted), trained people in\nbarrier nursing, as well as providing other assistance. A few treatment\ncourses of intravenous ribavirin have been retained at CDC to respond to an\nimported US hemorrhagic fever or to laboratory accidents. There are no US\nsources for intravenous ribavirin at this time. CDC's long-term project in\nSierra Leone has been moved to Guinea and that station is serving as a\nresource to provide Sierra Leone with both trained personnel (two are in\nSierre Leone at this time) and diagnostic testing. In addition, a number of\nthe former staff members are employed by MERLIN in patient care. The\nGovernment of Sierra Leone has donated a ward and committed additional staff.\nRecently, Dr. O. Tomori, an experienced Nigerian Lassa scientist with WHO\nmade an on-site assessment.\nThe situation points out three unresolved problems:\n1. Intravenous ribavirin is in short supply world-wide and is relatively\nexpensive. There may be alternative regimens using intravenous loading doses\nwith oral follow-through but these have not been tested. This drug probably\nalso has utility in [treatment of] the arenavirus hemorrhagic fevers of South\nAmerica, Congo-Crimean hemorrhagic fever, and possibly Rift Valley fever.\n2. Lassa fever is a major problem in west Africa year-in and year-out.\nThere are no accurate data, but the estimates of the number of infections\nrange from the tens to the hundreds of thousands annually. The incidence\nfluctuates by area and by year but it is always present and, even under the\nbest of circumstances, is unlikely to be adequately addressed by rodent\ncontrol.\nYet, like many other regionally important emerging infections, vaccine\ndevelopment escapes our economic priorities. The technical basis for a\nLassa vaccine was laid by Dave Auperin, Joe McCormick, and others in SPB\n[Special Pathogen Branch, CDC/Atlanta] several years ago. Another arenavirus\ndisease, Argentine hemorrhagic fever, has been controlled through a vaccine\nso this approach is practical and feasible, yet even in the case of AHF there\nare no immediate prospects for continuing vaccine production.\n3. Social and political unrest prevents long-term economic and health\ncare development as well as the longitudinal, solidly based research that\nleads to effective preventive and therapeutic solutions.\n(The usual disclaimer applies that this is not official USPHS opinion, etc.\nbut is provided to facilitate communications among interested parties.)\n---\nC. J. Peters, MD\nChief, Special Pathogens Branch\nDivision of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases\nNational Center for Infectious Diseases\nU.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\nAtlanta, GA 30333\n<cjp0@CIDDVD1.EM.CDC.GOV>\n[Given the numerous disease problems around the world, we all are fortunate\nto have Dr. Peters and his staff at the CDC keeping watch and actively\nintervening when invited and when they have adequate resources. Would that\nthey might have even more resources. In any event, we are greatly indebted\nto C.J. for contributing this information, as well as for providing his\nincisive insight. -- Mod CHC]\n.............................................................................\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
